diagnoses.name: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)
diagnoses.description: A dilation of the abdominal aorta (>1.5 times normal size), usually located below the renal arteries.
features: Abdominal or back pain when symptomatic
Risk factors: smoking, atherosclerosis, hypertension, male gender, age >50, family history
workup: Abdominal ultrasound (screening and surveillance)
CT angiogram (definitive diagnosis, especially for symptomatic disease)
Chest X-ray if dissection suspected
Blood pressure measurement in both arms
ECG to exclude cardiac causes
management: One-time ultrasound screening for men >65 with smoking history or family history
AAA <3cm: No further workup
AAA 3-3.9cm: Repeat ultrasound every 1-3 years
AAA 4-5.4cm: Repeat ultrasound every 6 months
AAA ≥5.5cm: Surgical repair (sometimes 5.0cm if Marfan's or small person)
All symptomatic AAA: Urgent surgical intervention regardless of size
Smoking cessation
Blood pressure control
Statin therapy
Antiplatelet therapy
pearls: Screening recommended for men 65-75 with smoking history
Consider screening in women >65 with risk factors
Regular surveillance imaging critical for size monitoring
Rapid growth (>0.5cm/year) or symptoms warrant intervention
Open surgical repair vs endovascular repair based on anatomy
Post-operative surveillance for endoleaks and complications
Family screening for first-degree relatives
Multidisciplinary approach with vascular surgery

diagnoses.name: Acute Coronary Syndrome (UA/NSTEMI/STEMI)
diagnoses.description: Spectrum of conditions from unstable angina to myocardial infarction resulting from coronary artery ischemia.
features: Chest pain (squeezing, pressure, substernal) - new, worsening, or at rest
Women, elderly, diabetics may present atypically without chest pain
Unstable angina: New/worsening chest pain or pain at rest without enzyme elevation
NSTEMI: Ischemia with cardiac enzyme elevation
STEMI: ST elevation with cardiac enzyme elevation
Coronary artery disease risk factors: HTN (most common), smoking, hyperlipidemia, DM, obesity, age (>45M/>55F), family history
workup: ECG within 10 minutes - repeat every 10 minutes if ACS suspected [WHY: Identifies STEMI requiring immediate PCI, localizes infarct territory, detects arrhythmias]
STEMI: ST elevation ≥1mm in ≥2 contiguous leads (II,III,aVF=inferior; V1-V4=anterior; I,aVL,V5-V6=lateral)
NSTEMI/Unstable angina: ST depression, T-wave inversion, or normal ECG
New LBBB = STEMI equivalent
Hyperacute T-waves = earliest sign of infarction
Cardiac biomarkers: Serial troponin measurements [WHY: Confirms myocardial necrosis, differentiates UA from NSTEMI, guides treatment intensity]
Troponin I (preferred) - rises 1-3h, peaks 24h, elevated up to 2 weeks
CK-MB for reinfarction (rises 4h, peaks 24h, returns to baseline 36-48h)
Serial troponins: Negative enzymes exclude MI by 8h (12-24h for high-risk)
Reinfarction: Troponin increase >20% or new rise
NOTE: Renal failure can falsely elevate troponin
Chest X-ray if alternative diagnosis suspected [WHY: Rules out aortic dissection, pneumothorax, pneumonia as chest pain causes]
Coronary anatomy: LAD (anterior LV), LCx (lateral LV, SA/AV node), RCA (inferior LV, RV, SA/AV node)
management: Immediate aspirin 325mg chewed + P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel 600mg/ticagrelor 180mg/prasugrel 60mg)
Oxygen only if hypoxic (SpO2 <94%)
Nitroglycerin SL 0.4mg q5min x3 PRN chest pain (contraindicated in RV MI, PDE-5 inhibitor use)
Morphine for refractory pain
Anticoagulation: Heparin bolus + infusion per protocol
Beta-blocker (metoprolol/atenolol) unless contraindicated
High-intensity statin (atorvastatin 40-80mg/rosuvastatin 20-40mg)
STEMI: PCI preferred (<90 min door-to-balloon) or thrombolysis if PCI unavailable
UA/NSTEMI: TIMI risk stratification - early invasive (≤24-48h) for score 3-7
TIMI 0-2: Medical therapy + stress testing if asymptomatic
Right-sided MI (40% of inferior MI): Avoid nitrates, consider fluid resuscitation
Bradycardia/AV block in inferior MI: Atropine/transcutaneous pacing
Cocaine-associated MI: Avoid beta-blockers, use benzodiazepines
Continuous telemetry monitoring for VT/VF (most common early death cause)
Pericarditis post-MI: Aspirin (avoid steroids for Dressler syndrome)
pearls: TIMI Risk Score (1 point each): Age≥65, ≥3 CAD RF, known CAD, ASA in 7d, ≥2 angina episodes in 24h, ST changes ≥0.5mm, positive enzymes
TIMI 3-7: Angiography within 24-48h; TIMI 0-2: Medical therapy + stress testing
Right-sided MI: Preload dependent - avoid nitrates, consider fluids for hypotension
Post-MI medications: ASA 81mg, P2Y12 inhibitor, beta-blocker, ACEI, high-intensity statin
EF <40%: Initiate GDMT for HFrEF (ACEI/ARB/ARNI, beta-blocker, MRA, SGLT2i)
Cardiac rehabilitation mandatory
Follow-up: CIS within 1-2 weeks, labs (CBC, CMP, Mg) prior to visit
Discharge documentation: History of GIB or No History of GIB
Nutrition consult for PCM evaluation
Protonix 40mg daily with DAPT for gastric protection
SL nitroglycerin 0.4mg q5min x3 PRN chest pain
Ambulate when chest pain-free
Remove transdermal nitro ASAP to assess for CP recurrence
Trend cardiac biomarkers q6h x3 sets
Keep NPO for LHC except medications
Complete angiogram checklist prior to cath
Engage physician early for high-risk patients

diagnoses.name: Acute Limb Ischemia (ALI)
diagnoses.description: Sudden decrease in limb perfusion requiring urgent intervention.
workup: Bedside vascular exam (Doppler)
CTA runoff (definitive imaging if stable)
Immediate vascular surgery consult
management: IV heparin anticoagulation
Analgesia, limb positioning (dependent)
Urgent revascularization (surgical embolectomy, bypass, thrombolysis)
pearls: Do not delay revascularization for imaging if limb immediately threatened
Report recurrent limb pain, numbness, weakness
Adherence to anticoagulation/antiplatelet therapy
Vascular surgery follow-up

diagnoses.name: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (AMI)
diagnoses.description: Insufficient blood supply to the intestines, often due to embolism or thrombosis.
features: Severe abdominal pain out of proportion to exam
workup: CTA abdomen (diagnostic)
Lactate, metabolic acidosis labs
Angiography (diagnosis + therapy in some cases)
management: Aggressive resuscitation (IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics)
Systemic anticoagulation (heparin)
Urgent revascularization (embolectomy, stent, bypass)
Surgery for peritonitis/necrosis
pearls: Do not delay operative intervention if peritonitis or shock
Adherence to anticoagulation if indicated
Report recurrent abdominal pain immediately
Vascular surgery and gastroenterology follow-up

diagnoses.name: Acute Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium, often presenting with chest pain.
features: Pleuritic chest pain (worse with inspiration, relieved by sitting up/leaning forward)
EKG: diffuse ST elevations and PR depressions
workup: EKG: diffuse ST elevation and PR depression
Troponins may be mildly elevated
Echocardiogram useful for pericardial effusion
CXR may show cardiomegaly if large effusion present
ESR/CRP elevated
Blood cultures if febrile; consider viral studies, autoimmune workup
management: NSAIDs and colchicine are first-line
Steroids if refractory
Hospitalize if patient has high-risk features (e.g., pericardial effusion, tamponade physiology, immunocompromised, post-MI, trauma)
pearls: Avoid anticoagulation in large effusion (tamponade risk)
Repeat echo if effusion suspected or symptoms persist
Monitor CRP for response
Cardiology follow-up in 1–2 weeks
Recurrence common - colchicine reduces recurrence rate
Differentiate from myocardial infarction (troponins, ECG pattern)

diagnoses.name: Angina
diagnoses.description: Chest pain or discomfort caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. Includes stable angina, variant (Prinzmetal) angina, and microvascular angina.
features: May radiate to jaw, neck, shoulders, arms, or back
May be accompanied by dyspnea, nausea, diaphoresis
Pattern varies by angina type (exertional vs rest vs microvascular)
workup: 12-lead ECG (may be normal at rest)
Cardiac biomarkers (troponin) to rule out MI
Stress testing (exercise or pharmacologic)
Coronary angiography for high-risk features
Advanced imaging (echo, nuclear, CT coronary angiography)
management: Risk factor modification (smoking cessation, BP control, lipid management, diabetes control)
Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin)
Statin therapy
Antianginal medications (beta-blockers, CCBs, nitrates)
Sublingual nitroglycerin for acute episodes
Revascularization (PCI or CABG) for appropriate candidates
pearls: Three main types: stable (exertional), variant (vasospastic), and microvascular
Always rule out acute coronary syndrome in new or worsening angina
Patients should carry sublingual nitroglycerin
Education: call EMS if chest pain persists >5 minutes or doesn't respond to nitroglycerin
Regular cardiology follow-up for optimization of medical therapy

subtypes.name: Stable (Chronic) Angina Pectoris
subtypes.description: Myocardial ischemia secondary to exertion (increased oxygen demand).
features: May radiate to jaw, neck, left arm
workup: ECG usually normal at rest
Stress testing: exercise or pharmacologic (dobutamine/adenosine)
Nuclear scans show decreased thallium uptake
Echocardiogram with dobutamine shows wall motion abnormalities
Coronary angiography if positive stress test + high-risk patient
PET if equivocal stress test + atypical symptoms
management: Lifestyle modifications (DASH diet, smoking cessation, weight loss, exercise)
Control hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia
Medications: aspirin, statin, beta blocker
Nitroglycerin as needed (decreases preload, relieves chest pain)
CCB if beta blockers contraindicated
Revascularization (PCI or CABG) if symptoms persist or anatomy is high risk
pearls: Coronary Artery Disease Risk Factors: HTN (most common), smoking, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, obesity, age, family history
Stress testing increases oxygen demand → ischemic changes (ST depression)
Neither stable nor Prinzmetal angina elevates cardiac enzymes
Indications for angiography: positive stress test + high-risk patient or equivocal stress test + atypical symptoms
Monitor symptom frequency, tolerance to meds
Regular risk factor modification follow-up
Carry nitroglycerin at all times, use for chest pain episodes
Call EMS if pain >5 minutes or not relieved by nitroglycerin
Cardiology follow-up; repeat stress testing if symptoms worsen

subtypes.name: Variant (Prinzmetal) Angina
subtypes.description: Ischemia secondary to coronary artery spasm.
features: Chest pain similar to stable angina but at rest
May be associated with arrhythmias during episodes
workup: ECG shows transient ST elevation that resolves after the episode (usually within 5–15 min)
Coronary angiography (often normal or mild CAD, may show spasm with provocation)
Ergonovine or acetylcholine provocation testing (specialized centers)
Holter monitoring to capture episodes
management: Calcium channel blockers and nitrates (relieve vasospasm)
Avoid beta blockers, as they may worsen symptoms
Smoking cessation (major trigger)
Treat underlying coronary artery disease if present
Long-acting nitrates for prevention
pearls: Monitor angina episodes, adjust CCB/nitrate therapy
Avoid precipitants (cocaine, smoking, cold exposure)
Adherence to CCB/nitrate therapy
Cardiology follow-up
May require implantable loop recorder if episodes infrequent
Consider autonomic dysfunction in some cases

subtypes.name: Microvascular Angina (Cardiac Syndrome X)
subtypes.description: Chest pain or discomfort due to coronary microvascular dysfunction.
features: Angina-like chest pain, often prolonged and not always exertional
workup: Stress testing (may be positive for ischemia)
Coronary angiography (normal/mild disease)
Coronary flow reserve testing (abnormal in microvascular angina)
management: Antianginal therapy: β-blockers, CCBs, nitrates (variable efficacy)
Risk factor modification (HTN, DM, lipids, obesity)
ACEi/ARB and statins may improve endothelial function
pearls: Symptom monitoring, risk factor management
Adherence to medications for angina and risk factor control
Seek urgent care for worsening or new typical angina symptoms
Cardiology follow-up

diagnoses.name: Aortic Dissection
diagnoses.description: Tearing of the tunica intima allowing blood to leak into the tunica media, creating a false lumen.
features: Sudden severe tearing chest pain or interscapular back pain
Risk factors: hypertension, Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos, males >40
workup: CT angiogram (CTA) - test of choice [WHY: Rapidly identifies dissection location, extent, and complications - critical for surgical planning in emergency setting]
Magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) - equal efficacy to CTA [WHY: Alternative when contrast contraindicated, excellent detail but takes longer - not ideal if unstable]
Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) - equal efficacy [WHY: Bedside test, identifies pericardial effusion/tamponade, aortic regurgitation - useful in unstable patients]
Chest X-ray: widened mediastinum (>8cm) [WHY: Quick screening test but only 60% sensitive - normal CXR doesn't rule out dissection]
ECG to exclude myocardial infarction [WHY: Dissection can involve coronary ostia causing MI, changes treatment approach - thrombolytics contraindicated]
Blood pressure measurement in both arms [WHY: >20 mmHg difference suggests subclavian involvement, indicates extent of dissection]
Neurological examination [WHY: Carotid involvement causes stroke, affects surgical approach and prognosis]
management: Surgical emergency - all unstable patients require intubation
Blood pressure control: beta-blockers first (SBP <100, HR <60)
Add nitroprusside if beta-blockers insufficient
Never start with nitroprusside alone (causes reflex tachycardia)
Type A (ascending aorta): Emergency surgical repair
Type B (descending aorta): Medical management unless rupture, end-organ ischemia, or refractory hypertension
Pain management with opioids
Serial imaging at 3, 6, and 12 months
pearls: Type A = proximal to left subclavian artery → surgery
Type B = distal to left subclavian artery → medical management
Beta-blockers are first-line for blood pressure control
Avoid vasodilators without beta-blocker coverage
Serial imaging to monitor for progression, redissections, new aneurysms
Genetic testing for connective tissue disorders
Family screening for hereditary conditions
Long-term beta-blocker and blood pressure management
Regular follow-up with cardiothoracic/vascular surgery

beta_blocker_monotherapy: Avoid vasodilator without β-blocker (reflex tachycardia worsens dissection)

instructions: Immediate ED evaluation for recurrent chest/back pain or neuro deficits

diagnoses.name: Aortic Regurgitation
diagnoses.description: Backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle due to aortic valve insufficiency.
features: Etiology: Aortic root dilation, congenital bicuspid valve, rheumatic disease (most common outside US)
Symptoms: Asymptomatic early; wide pulse pressure, 'water hammer' pulses
Murmur: Decrescendo diastolic murmur, blowing quality, best at left sternal border
workup: Transthoracic echo (severity, LV size/function, root/ascending aorta)
ECG (LVH, nonspecific changes)
CXR (cardiomegaly, aortic root dilation)
BNP for prognostic info in chronic AR
management: Treatment: Surgical correction
Afterload reduction (ACEi/ARB, nifedipine) may improve symptoms in severe AR if not surgical candidate
Treat underlying causes (syphilis, endocarditis, aortic root disease, etc.)
Symptomatic severe AR or LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF ≤50%): AVR (surgical preferred)
Asymptomatic severe AR with progressive LV dilation: AVR
pearls: Avoid in isolated severe AR — prolongs diastole and worsens regurgitant volume
Echo surveillance: mild q3–5y, moderate q1–2y, severe q6–12mo
Monitor for new dyspnea, chest pain, palpitations
Maintain good dental hygiene (endocarditis risk)
Wide pulse pressure and bounding pulses are characteristic
Diastolic murmur best heard at left sternal border with patient leaning forward

diagnoses.name: Aortic Stenosis
diagnoses.description: Narrowing of the aortic valve opening, restricting blood flow from the heart.
features: Common in elderly (calcification), congenital bicuspid valve, rheumatic disease
Murmur: systolic crescendo-decrescendo, best at 2nd right intercostal space, radiates to neck
Patients symptomatic with severe AS are at high risk of sudden death
workup: Transthoracic echo (valve area, mean gradient, jet velocity, LV function)
ECG (LVH)
CXR (post-stenotic dilation)
BNP in advanced disease prognostication
management: Definitive treatment: aortic valve replacement (surgical or balloon valvotomy)
Medical therapy does not halt progression; manage comorbidities (HTN, lipids)
Symptomatic severe AS or LVEF <50%: valve replacement (SAVR or TAVR)
Asymptomatic severe AS with very severe Vmax, rapid progression, or abnormal exercise test: consider intervention
Cardiology/heart-team evaluation for TAVR vs SAVR based on age, anatomy, surgical risk
pearls: Use vasodilators cautiously; avoid precipitous BP drops
Use with caution if preload dependent; monitor for hypotension
Echo surveillance: mild q3–5y, moderate q1–2y, severe q6–12mo or sooner if symptoms change
Educate on red-flag symptoms (syncope, angina, dyspnea) and prompt evaluation
Endocarditis prophylaxis only for high-risk prosthetic valve patients
TAVR Post-Operative Care by NP: Valve types (Edwards Sapien S3, Medtronic CoreValve)
Monitoring: Groin sites, peripheral pulses, EKG for LBBB/heart block
If new LBBB: monitor with PPM inpatient; if heart block develops, permanent pacemaker may be required
ECHO Post-Op: perform day 1; discharge after echo if no valve dysfunction (perivalvular leak or pericardial effusion)
Follow-up: If new LBBB, monitor with 2-week preventive device

diagnoses.name: Atrial Fibrillation / Flutter
diagnoses.description: Most common cardiac arrhythmia characterized by irregular atrial activation and ineffective atrial contraction, leading to increased stroke risk due to thrombus formation from stagnant blood.
features: Asymptomatic in up to 30% of patients
Atrial flutter: Regular atrial rate (~300 bpm) with saw-tooth P waves, variable ventricular response
Atrial fibrillation: Irregularly irregular rhythm, absent P waves, chaotic atrial activity
Thrombus formation risk increases after 48 hours of AF duration
workup: ECG: Definitive diagnostic test [WHY: Confirms rhythm diagnosis and guides treatment urgency]
AF: Irregularly irregular rhythm, absent P waves, chaotic baseline
AFlutter: Regular rhythm with saw-tooth pattern (~300 bpm atrial rate)
QRS width helps select antiarrhythmics (avoid class IC if wide)
Echocardiogram (TTE): Obtain once rate controlled [WHY: Assesses structural heart disease, guides treatment selection]
LA size predicts success of rhythm control (>4.5cm less likely to maintain SR)
LV function guides medication choice (avoid class IC if EF <40%)
Valve disease may be cause (mitral stenosis → AF)
Electrolytes and metabolic panel [WHY: Identifies reversible triggers that can terminate AF when corrected]
K+ <3.5 or Mg++ <1.7: Promote arrhythmias, correct before antiarrhythmics
TSH: Hyperthyroidism causes AF in 10-15% of patients
BMP: Kidney function guides anticoagulant dosing
CHADS₂-VASc score calculation [WHY: Quantifies stroke risk to guide anticoagulation decision]
Score ≥2: Anticoagulation reduces stroke risk by ~60%
Score 0 (men) or 1 (women): No anticoagulation needed
HAS-BLED score for bleeding risk [WHY: Balances stroke prevention benefit vs bleeding risk - score ≥3 indicates increased bleeding risk]
TEE if cardioversion planned and AF >48h or unknown duration [WHY: Excludes LA appendage thrombus before cardioversion - AF >48h = high thrombus risk]
Holter monitor or event recorder for paroxysmal AF [WHY: Documents arrhythmia burden and symptoms correlation - paroxysmal AF may be missed on single ECG]
Sleep study if sleep apnea suspected [WHY: OSA increases AF recurrence; CPAP reduces AF burden - treat OSA before ablation procedures for better outcomes]
management: Unstable patients (hypotension, ischemia, HF): Immediate synchronized cardioversion (200J → 300J → 360J)
AF <48h: Rate or rhythm control without anticoagulation (low thrombus risk)
AF >48h or unknown duration: Anticoagulation required before cardioversion
Rate control: Beta-blockers (metoprolol, atenolol) or non-DHP CCBs (diltiazem, verapamil)
Rhythm control: Amiodarone, flecainide, propafenone, sotalol (if no structural heart disease)
Digoxin: Acceptable if systolic dysfunction or hypotension limits other agents
Anticoagulation: DOACs preferred (apixaban, rivaroxaban, dabigatran) over warfarin
CHADS₂-VASc ≥2 (men) or ≥3 (women): Oral anticoagulation recommended
CHADS₂-VASc 0-1: Individualized decision based on risk factors
Pre-cardioversion: Anticoagulate 3-4 weeks before OR TEE-guided approach
Post-cardioversion: Continue anticoagulation 4 weeks minimum
Lifestyle modifications: Weight loss, exercise, alcohol moderation, sleep hygiene
Catheter ablation for symptomatic refractory AF
pearls: CHADS₂-VASc Score: CHF(1), HTN(1), Age≥75(2), DM(1), Stroke/TIA(2), Vascular disease(1), Age 65-74(1), Sex female(1)
CHADS₂-VASc ≥2: Anticoagulation recommended; 0-1: Consider anticoagulation
Rate control goals: Symptomatic <85 bpm, Asymptomatic <110 bpm
Beta-blockers first-line for rate control unless contraindicated
Amiodarone first-line for post-CABG AF or hemodynamically unstable
Digoxin requires K+ >4.0, renal dosing, careful monitoring
Cardioversion contraindicated with atrial thrombus, unstable angina, electrolyte abnormalities
Long-term anticoagulation may be required if thrombus risk persists
Cardiology EP follow-up for rhythm monitoring and ablation evaluation
Address modifiable risk factors: obesity, OSA, hypertension, alcohol
Patient education: Medication adherence, symptom recognition, when to seek care

class_ic: Avoid in structural heart disease or CAD (proarrhythmia)

instructions: Stroke prevention plan documented (OAC if indicated)
Education on rate/rhythm meds and when to seek care (worsening palpitations, syncope, chest pain)
follow_up: Cardiology EP follow‑up; consider sleep apnea evaluation and risk factor modification (weight loss, ETOH moderation)

diagnoses.name: Atrial Flutter
diagnoses.description: A type of supraventricular tachycardia resulting from a reentrant circuit in the right atrium.
workup: 12-lead ECG (diagnosis)
Telemetry/monitoring
Echo (assess structural disease, LA size, LV function)
Labs: thyroid, electrolytes
management: Rate control with β-blocker or nondihydropyridine CCB
Anticoagulation if duration >48h or unknown
Electrical cardioversion if unstable or refractory
Catheter ablation (cavotricuspid isthmus ablation) — high success, first-line definitive therapy
Ongoing anticoagulation guided by CHA₂DS₂-VASc
Rate vs rhythm strategy individualized
pearls: Adherence to anticoagulation if indicated
Monitor for recurrent palpitations
Lifestyle: reduce alcohol, caffeine, stimulants
Cardiology/EP follow-up, especially if considering ablation

diagnoses.name: Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)
diagnoses.description: A congenital heart defect characterized by a direct connection between both atria through a defect in the septum. More common in women.
features: Physical exam: systolic ejection murmur with fixed wide splitting of S2
Best heard at left upper sternal border (pulmonic area)
Risk for paradoxical emboli leading to stroke
workup: Echocardiogram (TEE > TTE): best diagnostic test
Bubble study with saline: confirms diagnosis (bubbles pass through defect)
ECG: RBBB, RVH, right axis deviation
Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly, enlarged RA/RV, prominent pulmonary artery
Cardiac catheterization: more invasive, not routinely necessary
Genetic testing: consider for associated syndromes
management: Percutaneous device closure: preferred for secundum ASD if suitable anatomy
Surgical closure: for primum ASD, sinus venosus defect, or unsuitable anatomy
Medical management: diuretics for heart failure, anticoagulation for AF
Anticoagulation: for AF or history of paradoxical embolus
Pulmonary hypertension management if present
Endocarditis prophylaxis: 6 months post-closure, then discontinue
Lifestyle modifications: exercise as tolerated, avoid dehydration
pearls: Three types: Primum (associated with anterior mitral valve cleft and MR), Secundum (most common), Sinus venosus (least common)
PFO is not true ASD (no septal tissue missing, flap-like opening)
Qp:Qs ratio >1.5 indicates significant shunt requiring closure
Monitor for AF, RV dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension in adulthood
Paradoxical emboli risk: consider closure if history of CVA/TIA
Serial echocardiograms to monitor shunt magnitude and RV function
Pregnancy generally well-tolerated but requires monitoring
Report new palpitations, syncope, dyspnea, or edema
Lifelong cardiology follow-up, especially if repaired in adulthood

diagnoses.name: Bradyarrhythmias (Sinus Node Dysfunction & AV Block)
diagnoses.description: Abnormally slow heart rate due to impaired electrical conduction, including various degrees of heart block.
features: Heart block symptoms vary by type and severity
workup: 12-lead ECG to identify block type [WHY: Determines block severity and urgency - 3rd degree requires immediate pacing, others may be observed]:
First Degree: PR interval >0.20 sec, all P waves conducted
Mobitz I (Wenckebach): PR interval progressively lengthens until dropped beat
Mobitz II: Dropped QRS without PR lengthening
Third Degree: Atria and ventricles beat independently, no conduction
Telemetry/Holter monitor for intermittent symptoms [WHY: Captures intermittent high-grade blocks that may be missed on single ECG, correlates symptoms with rhythm]
Labs (TSH, electrolytes, drug levels e.g. digoxin, beta-blockers) [WHY: Identifies reversible causes - hypothyroidism, hyperkalemia, drug toxicity can cause bradycardia]
Echo if structural disease suspected [WHY: Structural heart disease may cause conduction system fibrosis, affects pacemaker selection and prognosis]
Exercise testing if symptoms with exertion [WHY: Chronotropic incompetence suggests sinus node dysfunction, helps determine need for rate-responsive pacing]
Electrophysiology study if diagnosis unclear [WHY: Measures conduction intervals, predicts progression to higher-grade blocks, guides pacing decisions]
management: First Degree AV Block: No treatment (asymptomatic)
Mobitz I (Wenckebach): No treatment if asymptomatic; pacemaker if unstable; atropine if severe
Mobitz II: Consider pacemaker (progression to 3rd degree likely)
Third Degree AV Block: Pacemaker required (may be fatal without)
Atropine IV for symptomatic bradycardia
Temporary pacing if refractory to atropine
Treat reversible causes (ischemia, medications, hypothyroidism)
Permanent pacemaker for symptomatic sinus node dysfunction
Pacemaker for Mobitz II or complete heart block regardless of symptoms
pearls: No pacing for asymptomatic sinus bradycardia or Mobitz I
Mobitz II and 3rd degree blocks often require permanent pacing
Progressive PR prolongation in Mobitz I vs constant PR in Mobitz II
Third degree block: Independent atrial and ventricular rates
Pacemaker clinic follow-up if implanted
Monitor for progression in conduction disease
Review medications that may worsen conduction (beta-blockers, CCBs, digoxin)
Cardiology/EP follow-up for ongoing management
Driving restrictions may apply with symptomatic bradycardia

diagnoses.name: Cardiac Arrest / Sudden Cardiac Death
diagnoses.description: Sudden cessation of cardiac function, leading to unresponsiveness and absence of breathing.
workup: Immediate ACLS protocol [WHY: Time-critical emergency - brain death occurs within 4-6 minutes without circulation, immediate intervention is life-saving]
ECG rhythm identification (VF, pulseless VT, PEA, asystole) [WHY: Determines treatment approach - shockable rhythms (VF/VT) get immediate defibrillation, non-shockable get CPR + epinephrine]
management: Immediate defibrillation
CPR, epinephrine every 3–5 min, amiodarone
PEA, asystole: CPR, epinephrine, treat reversible causes (Hs & Ts)
Post-ROSC: Targeted temperature management, Coronary angiography if STEMI, ICU care
pearls: Family counseling, ICD consideration if appropriate
Cardiology, EP

diagnoses.name: Cardiogenic Shock
diagnoses.description: Inadequate cardiac output with tissue hypoperfusion despite adequate preload. Most common cause is acute MI.
features: Hemodynamic criteria: CI <2.2 L/min/m², PCWP >15 mmHg, SBP <90 or MAP <65 mmHg
Reflex tachycardia (except AV blocks, β-blocker overdose)
Pulmonary congestion if LV failure (rales, S3 gallop, JVD)
Mechanical causes: MI, heart failure (HFrEF), valvular damage (acute MR/AR)
Arrhythmogenic causes: V-Tac, V-Fib, A-Fib, SVT, AV blocks
workup: ECG: Acute ST changes, arrhythmias, conduction abnormalities
Echocardiogram: Wall motion abnormalities, valve function, LVEF assessment
Cardiac enzymes: Troponin elevation (assess for acute MI)
Chest X-ray: Pulmonary edema, cardiomegaly
Swan-Ganz catheter: ↑CVP (>15 mmHg), ↑PCWP (>18 mmHg), ↓CI, ↑SVR, ↓SvO2
Lactate levels: >2 mmol/L indicates tissue hypoperfusion
Shock severity: Mild (CI 1.8-2.2), Moderate (CI 1.5-1.8), Severe (CI <1.5)
management: Immediate: ABC assessment, oxygen, central venous and arterial access
Inotropes (first-line): Dobutamine 5-20 μg/kg/min, Milrinone 0.25-0.75 μg/kg/min
Vasopressors if hypotensive: Norepinephrine 0.1-2 μg/kg/min, Epinephrine 0.1-1 μg/kg/min
Mechanical support: IABP (↑diastolic pressure, ↓afterload), Impella, VA-ECMO
Treat underlying cause: Emergent PCI (MI), cardioversion (arrhythmias), valve repair
Supportive: Cautious fluids, diuretics for congestion, anticoagulation
Monitoring: Continuous hemodynamics, serial echos, watch for complications
pearls: IABP contraindications: Severe AR, aortic dissection, severe PAD
Inotrope contraindications: HOCM, severe AS, uncontrolled tachyarrhythmias
ECMO contraindications: Irreversible multiorgan failure, active bleeding
Early mechanical support improves outcomes in severe cases
Avoid excessive fluid administration (worsens pulmonary edema)
Documentation: 'Shock index 1.2 (elevated), lactate 3.8 mmol/L (tissue hypoperfusion)'

diagnoses.name: Chronic Venous Insufficiency / Varicose Veins
diagnoses.description: Inadequate venous return over a prolonged period, leading to varicosities and venous stasis.
workup: Duplex venous ultrasound (reflux, obstruction)
management: Compression stockings
Leg elevation, exercise, weight management
Skin care for stasis dermatitis
Endovenous ablation (laser, radiofrequency)
Sclerotherapy
Surgical vein stripping for severe/refractory disease
pearls: Daily use of compression stockings
Regular ambulation, avoid prolonged standing
Skin care with emollients, wound care if ulcers
Vascular follow-up; wound care clinic if ulcers present

diagnoses.name: Coarctation of the Aorta
diagnoses.description: A congenital narrowing of the descending aorta at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, just distal to the left subclavian artery, causing obstruction and increased left ventricular afterload.
features: Reduced blood pressure and diminished pulses in lower extremities
Differential cyanosis (pink upper body, blue lower body)
Weak femoral pulses compared to brachial pulses
workup: Echocardiogram: diagnostic test of choice, shows narrowing and collateral vessels
ECG: LVH from pressure overload
Chest X-ray: rib notching (erosion of ribs from collateral circulation), '3' sign (dilation of aortic notch)
CTA/MRA: most accurate for anatomy and collaterals
Cardiac catheterization: for intervention if needed
management: Surgical correction: preferred method (resection with end-to-end anastomosis)
Balloon angioplasty: for recurrent coarctation
Stent placement: for older patients or recurrent cases
Medical management: antihypertensives for hypertension
Endocarditis prophylaxis: if prosthetic material used
Monitor for aortic aneurysm at repair site
pearls: Associated with bicuspid aortic valve in 50-70% of cases
Critical coarctation presents in newborn period with shock
Serial blood pressure measurements in all extremities
Monitor for rebound hypertension post-repair
Risk of aortic dissection or aneurysm at repair site
Associated with Turner syndrome, genetic counseling recommended
Report hypertension, headache, leg pain, or unequal pulses
Lifelong cardiology follow-up
Exercise restrictions may be needed based on residual gradient

diagnoses.name: Common Cardiac Medications & Dosages
diagnoses.description: Comprehensive reference for cardiac medication dosing, indications, and administration guidelines
symptoms: Acute coronary syndromes requiring antiplatelet therapy
Heart failure requiring beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors
Angina management with nitrates and antianginals
examination: Blood pressure assessment for medication titration
workup: Renal function assessment (CrCl, eGFR)
Liver function tests
Electrolyte monitoring (K+, Mg++)
ECG monitoring for QT interval
INR monitoring for warfarin
Drug level monitoring (digoxin)
management: Antiplatelets:
• Aspirin: 81–325 mg PO daily
• Clopidogrel (Plavix): 75 mg PO daily (after 300–600 mg loading dose)
• Ticagrelor (Brilinta): 90 mg PO BID (after 180 mg loading dose)
• Prasugrel (Effient): 10 mg PO daily (after 60 mg loading dose)
Anticoagulants:
• Warfarin (Coumadin): 2–5 mg PO daily, titrated to INR (goal 2–3 for most indications)
• Apixaban (Eliquis): 5 mg PO BID (2.5 mg BID if ≥80 yrs, ≤60 kg, or Cr ≥1.5)
• Rivaroxaban (Xarelto): 20 mg PO daily with food (15 mg daily if CrCl 15–50)
• Dabigatran (Pradaxa): 150 mg PO BID (75 mg BID if CrCl 15–30)
• Enoxaparin (Lovenox): 1 mg/kg SQ q12h (1.5 mg/kg daily if normal renal, adjust if CrCl <30)
Beta Blockers:
• Metoprolol Tartrate (Lopressor): 25–50 mg PO BID (IV 5 mg q5min ×3 if ACS)
• Metoprolol Succinate (Toprol-XL): 25–200 mg PO daily (CHF start 12.5–25 mg daily)
• Carvedilol (Coreg): 3.125 mg PO BID → titrate to 25–50 mg BID
• Bisoprolol (Zebeta): 2.5–10 mg PO daily
• Atenolol (Tenormin): 25–100 mg PO daily
ACE Inhibitors / ARBs / ARNI:
• Lisinopril: 2.5–40 mg PO daily
• Enalapril: 2.5–20 mg PO BID
• Losartan: 25–100 mg PO daily (often divided BID)
• Valsartan: 80–320 mg PO daily (divided BID)
• Sacubitril/Valsartan (Entresto): 24/26 mg PO BID → titrate to 97/103 mg BID
Diuretics:
• Furosemide (Lasix): 20–80 mg PO daily or BID (IV for acute use)
• Bumetanide (Bumex): 0.5–2 mg PO or IV daily or BID
• Torsemide (Demadex): 10–40 mg PO daily
• Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ): 12.5–50 mg PO daily
• Spironolactone (Aldactone): 25–50 mg PO daily (CHF start 12.5–25 mg)
• Eplerenone (Inspra): 25–50 mg PO daily
Statins:
• Atorvastatin (Lipitor): 10–80 mg PO daily
• Rosuvastatin (Crestor): 5–40 mg PO daily
• Simvastatin (Zocor): 10–40 mg PO daily (not >20 mg with amlodipine)
• Pravastatin (Pravachol): 10–80 mg PO daily
Nitrates & Antianginals:
• Nitroglycerin SL (Nitrostat): 0.3–0.6 mg SL q5min ×3 max for acute angina
• Nitroglycerin Patch (Nitro-Dur): 0.2–0.8 mg/hr, applied 12–14 hr/day
• Isosorbide Mononitrate (Imdur): 30–60 mg PO daily (max 240 mg)
• Ranolazine (Ranexa): 500 mg PO BID → titrate to 1000 mg PO BID
Antiarrhythmics:
• Amiodarone: IV load: 150 mg over 10 min → 1 mg/min ×6h → 0.5 mg/min ×18h
• Amiodarone: PO: 800–1600 mg daily ×1–3 weeks, then 200–400 mg daily maintenance
• Sotalol: 80–160 mg PO BID (adjust for renal)
• Dofetilide (Tikosyn): 125–500 mcg PO BID (hospital initiation with QT monitoring)
• Digoxin: 0.125–0.25 mg PO/IV daily (lower in elderly/renal impairment)
pearls: Start beta-blockers at low doses and titrate slowly, especially in heart failure patients
Monitor renal function and potassium when using ACE inhibitors and ARBs
Warfarin requires frequent INR monitoring and dose adjustments
DOAC dosing must be adjusted for renal function and weight
Amiodarone requires monitoring of thyroid, liver, and pulmonary function
Statins should be dosed in the evening for optimal LDL reduction
Diuretics can cause electrolyte imbalances requiring monitoring
Nitroglycerin patches should have a nitrate-free interval to prevent tolerance
Antiplatelet therapy duration depends on clinical indication and stent type
Beta-blockers should not be abruptly discontinued due to rebound hypertension
ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy and bilateral renal artery stenosis
Spironolactone requires potassium monitoring due to hyperkalemia risk
Dofetilide initiation requires inpatient telemetry monitoring
Digoxin has a narrow therapeutic index requiring level monitoring
Consider drug interactions when combining cardiac medications

diagnoses.name: Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)
diagnoses.description: A pump problem causing decreased perfusion to tissues and underoxygenation, due to filling problems (diastolic dysfunction) or pumping problems (systolic dysfunction).
features: Most common symptoms: fatigue and shortness of breath
Left-sided HF: crackles, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
Right-sided HF: jugular venous distension, hepatojugular reflex, pedal edema, ascites
Acute exacerbation: pulmonary edema, orthopnea, PND
Chronic symptoms: exercise intolerance, weight gain, abdominal discomfort
workup: Echocardiogram: most useful test [WHY: Determines EF (systolic vs diastolic HF), assesses wall motion, valve function, guides therapy]
EF <40% = HFrEF (systolic dysfunction) → ACEi/ARB + beta-blocker mortality benefit
EF ≥50% = HFpEF (diastolic dysfunction) → symptom management, treat comorbidities
ECG: Always obtain [WHY: Identifies ischemia (treatable cause), arrhythmias (AF common in HF), conduction delays]
Q waves suggest old infarct (ischemic cardiomyopathy)
LBBB + EF ≤35% + QRS ≥150ms = candidate for CRT device
Chest X-ray: Essential for dyspnea evaluation [WHY: Confirms pulmonary congestion vs other causes, monitors treatment response]
Findings: cardiomegaly, cephalization, Kerley B lines, pleural effusions
BNP/NT-proBNP: Key diagnostic test [WHY: Differentiates heart failure from other dyspnea causes (COPD, pneumonia)]
BNP >400 pg/mL suggests CHF, <100 pg/mL rules out CHF
Trending levels guides diuretic therapy effectiveness
Cardiac enzymes (troponin): Rule out acute MI [WHY: MI can precipitate HF exacerbation, changes treatment approach]
Stress testing: Risk stratification [WHY: Assesses exercise capacity, detects ischemia as reversible cause]
Laboratory panel: CBC, CMP, TSH, iron studies [WHY: Identifies precipitating factors and complications]
Anemia worsens HF symptoms
Kidney function guides medication dosing (ACEi/ARB/diuretics)
Thyroid disease can cause or worsen HF
Iron deficiency common in HF, impacts exercise tolerance
Sleep study: Consider if OSA suspected [WHY: OSA worsens HF outcomes, CPAP therapy improves symptoms]
management: Diastolic dysfunction: no proven mortality-reducing medications; focus on symptom management and comorbidities
Systolic dysfunction: ACEi/ARB/ARNI and beta-blockers are main therapies (class effect on mortality)
Never combine ACEi with ARB
Acute exacerbation 'LMNOP': Loop diuretics, Morphine, Nitrates, Oxygen, Position (upright)
Refractory cases: inotropes (milrinone, dobutamine) or mechanical support
Device therapy: ICD for EF ≤35%, CRT for LBBB + QRS ≥150ms + EF ≤35%
Advanced therapy: LVAD or heart transplant for refractory cases
Mandatory discharge medications: ACEi/ARNI/ARB, beta-blocker, diuretic, MRA, nitrates
pearls: Systolic dysfunction: EF <50%, decreased contractility; Diastolic dysfunction: normal/high EF, poor relaxation
Systolic etiology: CAD, HTN, cardiomyopathy, valvular disease, diabetes
Diastolic etiology: HTN, ischemia, age, cardiomyopathy, post-MI scarring
Daily weights and low-sodium diet essential for monitoring
Diuretic compliance critical - emphasize at every visit
Accurate I/Os and volume status assessment
Consider nephrology consult in advanced cardiorenal syndrome
CXR prior to discharge to document improvement
Early post-discharge follow-up within 7 days
Vaccinations and guideline-directed preventive care

diagnoses.name: Constrictive Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Scarring of the pericardium that leads to thickening and restricts diastolic filling. Most common causes are idiopathic and viral.
features: Pericardial knock (abrupt cessation of ventricular filling)
Kussmaul sign (jugular venous distension increases during inspiration)
workup: EKG: nonspecific ST and T wave changes
Chest X-ray: may show calcification
Echocardiogram: pericardial thickening, decreased diastolic filling
CT scan: pericardial thickening and/or calcification
Cardiac catheterization: equalization of diastolic pressures
management: Diuretics and pericardiectomy
Treat underlying cause if identified
Salt restriction and fluid management
Surgical pericardiectomy for symptomatic patients
pearls: Monitor for worsening right-sided HF symptoms
Consider referral for surgical pericardiectomy evaluation
Cardiology/surgical follow-up
Differentiate from restrictive cardiomyopathy
Pericardiectomy has high success rate when performed early
Post-operative monitoring for recurrence

diagnoses.name: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
diagnoses.description: Formation of a blood clot in a deep vein, usually in the legs, arising from Virchow's triad: hypercoagulability, stasis, and endothelial injury.
features: Unilateral lower extremity pain, erythema, swelling
Homan's sign (pain with dorsiflexion of ankle) - not sensitive/specific but may appear on exams
Warmth and tenderness along the vein
workup: Modified Wells Criteria for pretest probability:
- Active cancer (1 point)
- Paralysis, paresis, immobilization of lower extremities (1 point)
- Recently bedridden >3 days or surgery within 4 weeks (1 point)
- Localized tenderness along distribution of deep veins (1 point)
- Entire leg swollen (1 point)
- Calf swelling ≥3 cm (1 point)
- Pitting edema (1 point)
- Collateral superficial veins (1 point)
- Previously documented DVT (1 point)
- Alternative diagnosis more likely than DVT (-2 points)
Interpretation: Score ≤2 = low probability → order D-dimer; Score ≥2 = high probability → order duplex ultrasound
D-dimer: Normal virtually excludes DVT; Elevated requires imaging
Duplex ultrasound: Diagnostic test of choice
Do not get D-dimer in high probability patients
Do not screen for hypercoagulable states during initial workup
management: Anticoagulation: Start immediately with heparin (unfractionated or LMWH), fondaparinux, or factor Xa inhibitors
Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs: rivaroxaban, apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban) preferred for long-term
Warfarin: Requires bridging with heparin until INR therapeutic (2-3); overlap for at least 5 days
Pregnancy: Treat with LMWH, not warfarin (teratogenic)
Duration: Minimum 3 months; Provoked DVT = 3-6 months; Cancer patients = lifelong
Contraindications to anticoagulation: Consider IVC filter placement
Compression stockings for symptom relief and post-thrombotic syndrome prevention
Mobilization as tolerated with anticoagulation
pearls: Risk factors: Hypercoagulability (OCP, pregnancy, cancer), Stasis (immobilization, travel), Endothelial injury (surgery, trauma)
Age >65, obesity, prior DVT/PE additional risk factors
Some patients have no identifiable risk factors (unprovoked DVT)
Active bleeding or high bleeding risk: Consider IVC filter if acute proximal DVT
Monitor for pulmonary embolism signs (dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia)
Medication adherence critical - emphasize compliance
Report bleeding, bruising, shortness of breath, chest pain
Follow-up with hematology/PCP for duration decisions
Recurrence risk assessment for indefinite anticoagulation decisions

diagnoses.name: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM)
diagnoses.description: Disease of the heart muscle causing ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction, leading to heart failure.
features: Symptoms identical to congestive heart failure
workup: Echocardiogram: Dilated ventricles, decreased EF (<40%), global hypokinesis [WHY: Confirms diagnosis, quantifies severity, guides ICD/CRT candidacy, monitors treatment response]
ECG: Non-specific changes, arrhythmias, conduction abnormalities, LVH [WHY: LBBB with QRS ≥150ms indicates CRT candidacy, arrhythmias common in DCM]
Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly, pulmonary congestion, pleural effusions [WHY: Shows heart enlargement and fluid status, monitors treatment response]
Cardiac MRI: Assess fibrosis, infiltrative disease, viability [WHY: Distinguishes ischemic vs non-ischemic etiology, detects infiltrative diseases, assesses viability for interventions]
Labs: BNP/NT-proBNP elevated, troponin, TSH, iron studies, viral titers [WHY: BNP guides treatment, TSH/iron deficiency are reversible causes, viral titers may identify myocarditis]
Genetic testing: Consider in familial cases [WHY: 20-35% of DCM is familial, affects family screening recommendations and prognosis]
Endomyocardial biopsy: If infiltrative disease suspected [WHY: Identifies specific treatable causes like sarcoidosis, amyloidosis, hemochromatosis]
Coronary angiography: Rule out ischemic etiology [WHY: Ischemic cardiomyopathy has different prognosis and treatment, revascularization may improve function]
management: Guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT): ACEI/ARB/ARNI, beta-blocker, MRA, SGLT2i
Diuretics: Loop diuretics for volume overload (furosemide, bumetanide)
Anticoagulation: For AF, thrombus, or EF <35%
ICD: For secondary prevention or primary prevention if EF ≤35% after 3 months GDMT
CRT: If EF ≤35% with LBBB and QRS ≥150ms
Treat underlying causes: Alcohol cessation, thyroid replacement, chelation for hemochromatosis
Lifestyle modifications: Sodium restriction, daily weights, exercise as tolerated
Advanced therapies: LVAD, heart transplant for refractory cases
Monitor for arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death risk
pearls: Most common cardiomyopathy type
Idiopathic etiology most common, ischemic second most common
Serial echocardiograms to monitor EF and response to therapy
Daily weights and low-sodium diet (<2g/day)
ACEI/ARB/ARNI cornerstone of therapy - improve survival by 15-35%
Beta-blockers reduce mortality by 35% in HFrEF
MRA prevent potassium/magnesium wasting, reduce SCD
SGLT2i reduce HF hospitalizations independent of diabetes
ICD reduces SCD by 50-60% in appropriate patients
Cardiology/HF clinic follow-up every 3-6 months
Call for rapid weight gain (>2kg/week), worsening dyspnea, edema

diagnoses.name: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM)
diagnoses.description: Primary myocardial disease characterized by dilated ventricles and impaired systolic function in the absence of abnormal loading conditions or coronary artery disease.
workup: Echocardiogram: Key diagnostic test [WHY: Shows dilated LV, reduced EF (<40%), global hypokinesis, differentiates from ischemic cardiomyopathy]
ECG: Often abnormal [WHY: Identifies arrhythmias (common complication), conduction abnormalities, helps guide device therapy]
Findings: nonspecific ST-T changes, left bundle branch block, atrial fibrillation
Chest X-ray: Shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion [WHY: Confirms heart failure, monitors treatment response]
BNP/NT-proBNP: Elevated, correlates with severity [WHY: Confirms heart failure diagnosis, monitors treatment response]
Cardiac catheterization: Rule out coronary disease [WHY: Distinguishes non-ischemic from ischemic cardiomyopathy, changes treatment approach]
Cardiac MRI: Advanced imaging [WHY: Assesses for fibrosis, infiltrative disease, guides prognosis and therapy decisions]
Laboratory studies: CBC, CMP, TSH, iron studies [WHY: Identifies reversible causes and comorbidities]
Viral serologies and autoimmune workup: If indicated [WHY: Identifies treatable inflammatory causes]
Genetic testing: Consider if family history [WHY: Identifies inherited forms, guides family screening]
Endomyocardial biopsy: Rarely needed [WHY: Reserved for suspected infiltrative disease or giant cell myocarditis]
management: Heart failure medications (4-pillar therapy): ARNI/ACEi/ARB, β-blocker, MRA, SGLT2 inhibitor
Diuretics: For volume overload symptoms [WHY: Improves symptoms and functional capacity]
ICD therapy: Consider if EF ≤35% after 3 months optimal medical therapy [WHY: Prevents sudden cardiac death]
CRT therapy: If EF ≤35%, LBBB, QRS ≥150 ms [WHY: Improves symptoms, functional status, and mortality]
Anticoagulation: If atrial fibrillation or LV thrombus [WHY: Prevents thromboembolic complications]
Treat underlying causes: Alcohol cessation, thyroid optimization, nutritional deficiencies
Advanced therapies: LVAD, heart transplant for refractory Stage D heart failure
Lifestyle modifications: Low sodium diet, fluid restriction, daily weights, exercise as tolerated
pearls: Most common cause of heart failure in young adults
Can be familial (30-40% of cases) - screen family members with echo/ECG
Alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy can improve with complete abstinence
Peripartum cardiomyopathy occurs in last month of pregnancy to 5 months postpartum
Sudden cardiac death risk highest in younger patients and those with ventricular arrhythmias
Recovery of LV function possible in 10-40% of cases, especially with recent onset
Consider heart transplant evaluation early in young patients with refractory symptoms
Avoid pregnancy until LV function recovers due to high maternal mortality risk
Annual influenza and pneumococcal vaccination recommended

diagnoses.name: Distributive Shock
diagnoses.description: Shock due to massive vasodilation with decreased SVR. ONLY shock type with ↓↓SVR.
features: Neurogenic: Spinal cord injury → ↓sympathetic tone → hypotension + bradycardia
Septic: Systemic infection → ↑cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α) → inflammation + vasodilation
Anaphylactic: Allergic reaction → ↑histamine/leukotrienes → vasodilation + capillary leak
workup: Neurogenic: Neurologic exam, spinal imaging, assess for trauma
Septic: Blood cultures, urinalysis, chest X-ray, procalcitonin, source identification
Anaphylactic: History of allergen exposure, elevated tryptase levels
SIRS criteria (sepsis): Temp >38°C or <36°C, HR >90, RR >20, WBC >12,000 or <4,000
management: Neurogenic: Spinal immobilization, vasopressors (phenylephrine, norepinephrine), atropine for bradycardia
Septic: 30 mL/kg IV fluid bolus + broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour + source control
Anaphylactic: STAT IM epinephrine 0.3-0.5 mg + H1/H2 antihistamines + steroids + airway management
Vasopressors if MAP <65 mmHg: Norepinephrine (first-line), vasopressin, epinephrine
Goal MAP ≥65 mmHg for adequate organ perfusion
pearls: Distributive is ONLY shock with ↓↓SVR (others compensate with ↑SVR)
Neurogenic + cardiogenic are ONLY shocks with hypotension + bradycardia
Epinephrine contraindicated in cocaine intoxication
Early antibiotics in sepsis critical (1-hour bundle)
Documentation: 'Warm extremities consistent with distributive physiology'

diagnoses.name: Electrophysiology (EP) Guidelines
diagnoses.description: Comprehensive guidelines for electrophysiology procedures including device implants, ablations, and perioperative management
examination: Pre-procedure assessment including vital signs, ECG, and baseline rhythm
workup: ECG: Baseline rhythm assessment
CXR: Pre-procedure chest imaging
Labs: CBC, BMP, coagulation studies
Device interrogation if applicable
TEE if indicated for LAA closure
Cardiac imaging as indicated
management: Amiodarone Loading Protocols:
Oral loading: 800-1600mg daily divided doses for 1-2 weeks, then maintenance 200-400mg daily
IV loading: 150mg over 10 minutes, then 1mg/min x 6 hours, then 0.5mg/min x 18 hours
Monitoring: QTc, LFTs, TFTs weekly during loading, then monthly
Interactions: Warfarin (increase INR), digoxin (increase levels), beta-blockers (bradycardia)
Holding DOACs/Anti-Platelets for Implants:
Apixaban (Eliquis): Hold 24-48 hours pre-op, restart 24 hours post-op
Rivaroxaban (Xarelto): Hold 24-48 hours pre-op, restart 24 hours post-op
Dabigatran (Pradaxa): Hold 24-48 hours pre-op (48-72 if CrCl <50), restart 24 hours post-op
Edoxaban (Savaysa): Hold 24-48 hours pre-op, restart 24 hours post-op
Warfarin: Hold 4-5 days pre-op, restart evening of procedure or next day
Aspirin: Hold 5-7 days pre-op for high bleeding risk procedures
Clopidogrel (Plavix): Hold 5-7 days pre-op
Ticagrelor (Brilinta): Hold 5-7 days pre-op
Prasugrel (Effient): Hold 7-10 days pre-op
Pre-operative Implant Guidelines:
NPO after midnight, clear liquids until 2 hours pre-op
Hold ACEI/ARB on day of procedure
Continue beta-blockers unless bradycardia
Antibiotic prophylaxis 30-60 min pre-op (cefazolin 2g IV or vancomycin if PCN allergic)
Sedation assessment and airway evaluation
Pre-procedure device interrogation and programming
Consent discussion including risks, benefits, alternatives
Post-operative Implant Guidelines:
Bed rest for 12-24 hours post-implant
Arm immobilization for 24-48 hours (left-sided implants)
Vital signs monitoring every 15-30 min for first 2 hours, then hourly
Telemetry monitoring for 24-48 hours
Pain management: acetaminophen, opioids if needed
Anti-emetics as needed
Early mobilization protocol starting 12-24 hours post-op
Wound Care Instructions:
Keep dressing dry and intact for 24-48 hours
No showers for 48 hours, sponge baths only
Inspect incision daily for signs of infection (redness, drainage, warmth)
No heavy lifting >10 lbs or strenuous activity for 4-6 weeks
No driving for 1 week (or longer if ICD implanted)
Follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks for wound check
Report any fever >101.5°F, increased pain, or drainage immediately
Post-operative Diagnostics:
CXR: Post-procedure to confirm lead positions and rule out pneumothorax
Device interrogation: Pre-discharge and at follow-up
ECG: Post-procedure and before discharge
Labs: CBC, BMP if indicated for bleeding or electrolyte abnormalities
Holter monitor: If symptoms or arrhythmia concerns
Echo: If new murmur or concern for tamponade
Repeat device check: 1-2 weeks post-implant, then every 3-6 months
Pacemaker Generator Selection Guidelines (AHA/ACC 1998):
Single-Chamber Atrial Pacemaker:
Sinus Node Dysfunction:
• Appropriate if no suspected abnormality of AV conduction and no increased risk for future AV block
• Maintenance of AV synchrony during pacing desired
• Rate response available if desired
AV Block: Not appropriate
Neurally Mediated Syncope or Carotid Sinus Hypersensitivity: Not appropriate (unless AV block systematically excluded)
Single-Chamber Ventricular Pacemaker:
Sinus Node Dysfunction:
• Maintenance of AV synchrony during pacing not necessary
• Rate response available if desired
AV Block:
• Appropriate in chronic atrial fibrillation or other atrial tachycardia where maintenance of AV synchrony is unnecessary
• Rate response available if desired
Neurally Mediated Syncope or Carotid Sinus Hypersensitivity:
• Appropriate in chronic atrial fibrillation or other atrial tachyarrhythmia
• Rate response available if desired
Dual-Chamber Pacemaker:
Sinus Node Dysfunction:
• AV synchrony during pacing desired
• Suspected abnormality of AV conduction or increased risk for future AV block
• Rate response available if desired
AV Block:
• AV synchrony during pacing desired
• Atrial pacing desired
• Rate response available if desired
Neurally Mediated Syncope or Carotid Sinus Hypersensitivity:
• Appropriate if sinus mechanism present
• Rate response available if desired
Single-Lead, Atrial-Sensing Ventricular Pacemaker:
Sinus Node Dysfunction: Not appropriate
AV Block:
• Appropriate if normal sinus node function and no need for atrial pacing
• Desire to limit number of pacemaker leads
Neurally Mediated Syncope or Carotid Sinus Hypersensitivity: Not appropriate
ICD Implementation Guidelines (AHA/ACC/HRS):
Secondary Prevention:
• Documented episodes of cardiac arrest due to VT/VF (not due to transient or reversible cause)
• Documented sustained VT (either spontaneous or induced by EP), not associated with AMI, and not due to a transient or reversible cause
Primary Prevention:
• Documented familial or inherited conditions with high risk of life-threatening VT (e.g., Long QT Syndrome, Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy)
Ischemic Cardiomyopathy with the Following:
• Prior MI > 40 days
• Prior revascularization > 90 days (3 months) on medical therapy
• LVEF ≤ 35%
• VT/VF inducible and sustained at EP study
Non-Ischemic Dilated Cardiomyopathy with All of the Following:
• Documented duration > 3 months on medical therapy
• NYHA Class II or III
• LVEF ≤ 35%
Severe CHF with All of the Following:
• Meets coverage requirements for CRT
• QRS > 140 ms
• MI < 40 days
Exclusion Criteria for ICD:
• CABG or PCI < 90 days
• NYHA Class IV who do not meet CRT requirements
• Candidate for coronary revascularization
• VT/VF or CHF due to reversible cause
• No reasonable expectation of survival > 1 year with good functional status
Class I Recommendation for CRT:
• LVEF ≤ 35%
• Dilated LV cavity with severe systolic dysfunction
• Recurrent CHF (NYHA Class III or ambulatory Class IV) despite optimal therapy, > 3–9 months duration
• QRS duration ≥ 140 ms (best responders: LBBB with QRS ≥ 150 ms)
• Ventricular tachyarrhythmia (VT/VF)
• Sinus rhythm with best response (AV synchrony and VV synchrony)
QT Prolonging Medications:
Antimicrobials:
• Azanamycin, Azithromycin, Bactrim, Ciprofloxacin, Chloroquine, Clarithromycin
• Erythromycin, Fluconazole, Gatifloxacin, Gemifloxacin, Halofantrine, Imipramine
• Itraconazole, Ketoconazole, Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin, Ofloxacin, Pentamidine
• Ritonavir, Sparfloxacin, Telithromycin, Voriconazole
Antidepressants:
• Amitriptyline, Citalopram, Clomipramine, Desipramine, Doxepin, Escitalopram
• Fluoxetine, Nortriptyline, Paroxetine, Protriptyline, Sertraline, Trazodone
• Trimipramine, Venlafaxine
Antiemetics:
• Dolasetron, Domperidone, Droperidol, Granisetron, Ondansetron
Antipsychotics:
• Chlorpromazine, Clozapine, Haloperidol, Mesoridazine, Paliperidone, Pimozide
• Quetiapine, Risperidone, Sertindole, Thioridazine, Ziprasidone
Antiarrhythmics:
• Amiodarone, Disopyramide, Dofetilide, Dronedarone, Flecainide, Ibutilide
• Nicardipine, Procainamide, Quinidine, Sotalol
Anticonvulsants:
• Felbamate, Fosphenytoin, Phenytoin
Other Drugs:
• Alfuzosin, Astemizole, Amantadine, Bepridil, Cisapride, Diphenhydramine
• Epirubicin, Famotidine, Fingolimod, Galantamine, Indapamide, Lapatinib
• Levomethadyl, Lithium, Methadone, Moxifloxacin, Nilotinib, Octreotide
• Oxytocin, Probucol, Ranolazine, Sunitinib, Tacrolimus, Tamoxifen
• Terfenadine, Tizanidine, Vandetanib, Verdenafil
Orthostatic Hypotension Therapy Options:
Midodrine (Alpha-Adrenergic Agonist):
• Dose: 10 mg TID (daytime hours, start 2.5 mg)
• Dose Adjustments: Use caution in patients with renal impairment
Droxidopa (Alpha-/Beta-Adrenergic Agonist):
• Dose: 100 mg TID, uptitrated Q24–48h as needed (max 1,800 mg/day)
• Dose Adjustments: None
Fludrocortisone (Corticosteroid):
• Dose: 0.1 mg daily to 0.3 mg daily; uptitrate weekly as needed (max 1 mg/day)
• Dose Adjustments: Doses >0.3 mg/day may cause unwanted side effects
Pyridostigmine (Acetylcholinesterase Inhibitor):
• Dose: 60 mg TID daily
• Dose Adjustments: Lower doses may be required in patients with renal disease
Atomoxetine (Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor):
• Dose: 18 mg daily
• Dose Adjustments: Dose reduction required in hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh B/C)
Pseudoephedrine (Alpha-/Beta-Adrenergic Agonist):
• Dose: 30 mg daily
• Dose Adjustments: None
Octreotide (Somatostatin Analog):
• Dose: 12.5–50 µg daily
• Dose Adjustments: None
LifeVest (Wearable Cardioverter Defibrillator) Indications:
Primary Prevention:
• LVEF ≤ 35% and MI, NICM, or other DCM (including during the 40-day ICD waiting period)
Post-MI:
• After recent MI (coverage during the 40-day ICD waiting period)
LifeVest Considerations:
Coverage Periods:
• Before and after CABG or PTCA (coverage during the 90-day ICD waiting period)
• Listed for cardiac transplant
• Recently diagnosed nonischemic cardiomyopathy (coverage during the 3–9 month ICD waiting period)
• NYHA Class IV heart failure
Not appropriate for patients with terminal disease and life expectancy < 1 year
Notes:
• ICD indications when patient condition delays or prohibits ICD implantation

• LifeVest Order Form Link: LifeVest Order Form

• NPO after midnight

• Labs: Creatinine, H&H

• Benadryl 25 mg IVP × 1
pearls: Individualize anticoagulation management based on thromboembolic risk vs bleeding risk
Document all medication holds and resumption plans clearly
Ensure proper antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infection
Early mobilization reduces DVT risk but must balance with bleeding risk
Patient education is crucial for wound care and activity restrictions
Close follow-up essential for device programming and monitoring

Consider bridging anticoagulation for high-risk patients when appropriate
Pacemaker selection should prioritize AV synchrony when sinus node function is preserved
Single-chamber ventricular pacing is appropriate when atrial fibrillation is present

Rate-responsive pacing should be considered for patients with chronotropic incompetence
Minimize lead burden when possible while maintaining appropriate pacing functionality
ICD therapy is indicated for both secondary and primary prevention of sudden cardiac death
LVEF ≤ 35% is a key criterion for primary prevention ICD in both ischemic and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy
Wait at least 40 days post-MI and 90 days post-revascularization before ICD implantation
CRT is indicated when ICD criteria are met plus QRS ≥ 140ms and severe systolic dysfunction
Consider genetic testing in patients with suspected inherited arrhythmia syndromes

Avoid combining multiple QT prolonging medications when possible
Consider drug-drug interactions that may potentiate QT prolongation

Orthostatic hypotension often responds to volume expansion and vasopressor therapy
Midodrine should be dosed during daytime hours to avoid supine hypertension
Fludrocortisone requires careful monitoring for fluid retention and hypokalemia
LifeVest provides temporary protection during ICD waiting periods or when permanent ICD is contraindicated
Patient compliance and comfort are crucial for successful LifeVest therapy
Consider underlying causes of orthostatic hypotension before initiating pharmacologic therapy
LifeVest is particularly useful for patients awaiting cardiac transplant or with recent NICM diagnosis
Comprehensive iodine allergy preparation reduces contrast reaction risk in cath lab procedures
Anticoagulation management is critical for cath lab procedures to balance bleeding and thrombosis risk
Patient positioning assessment prevents complications during prolonged cath lab procedures
LifeVest order form and patient education are essential for successful wearable defibrillator therapy

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure with Preserved EF (HFpEF)
diagnoses.description: A clinical syndrome characterized by signs and symptoms of heart failure with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction.
workup: ECG
BNP or NT‑proBNP (often elevated but lower than HFrEF for similar symptoms)
Transthoracic echocardiogram (diastolic function, LA size, LV mass, RV/pulmonary pressures)
CBC, CMP, Mg, TSH, fasting glucose/A1c, lipids
CXR (congestion), consider sleep apnea screening
management: Aggressive treatment of comorbidities: hypertension, obesity, diabetes, CKD, AF, OSA
Diuretics for volume control (avoid over‑diuresis)
Exercise training / cardiac rehab improves functional capacity
ACEi/ARB/ARNI or CCB per BP and tolerance
MRA (spironolactone) may reduce HF hospitalizations in selected patients
SGLT2 inhibitor (empagliflozin/dapagliflozin) reduces HF hospitalizations
Atrial fibrillation management (rate/rhythm control) and anticoagulation per CHA₂DS₂‑VASc
Manage underlying left‑sided filling pressures; PAH‑specific drugs not beneficial unless Group 1 PAH
pearls: Avoid routine nitrates for HFpEF symptom relief (no benefit)
Use caution with aggressive preload reduction; patients are preload sensitive
Optimize comorbidity control; periodic reassessment of diastolic parameters
Titrate diuretics to weight and symptoms; monitor renal function and electrolytes
Lifestyle and exercise prescription; weight loss for obesity
Primary cardiology follow‑up within 2–4 weeks; earlier if recent decompensation

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure with Reduced EF (HFrEF)
diagnoses.description: A clinical syndrome characterized by signs and symptoms of heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction.
workup: ECG
BNP or NT‑proBNP
Transthoracic echocardiogram (EF, structure, valves, RV)
CBC, CMP (BUN/Cr, LFTs), Mg, TSH
Iron studies (if anemia or suspected deficiency)
CXR (pulmonary edema, cardiomegaly)
management: ARNI (sacubitril/valsartan preferred) OR ACEi/ARB if ARNI not feasible
Evidence β‑blocker (carvedilol, metoprolol succinate, bisoprolol)
MRA (spironolactone or eplerenone)
SGLT2 inhibitor (dapagliflozin or empagliflozin)
Loop diuretic (e.g., furosemide, bumetanide) titrated to euvolemia; consider thiazide add‑on for diuretic resistance
Ivabradine (sinus rhythm, HR ≥70 bpm on max β‑blocker, EF ≤35%)
Hydralazine/Isosorbide dinitrate (African ancestry or ACEi/ARB intolerance)
Vericiguat (selected high‑risk patients with recent decompensation)
Digoxin (rate control in AF or symptoms despite GDMT; narrow TI)
ICD: EF ≤35% despite ≥3 months GDMT and good functional status
CRT: LBBB with QRS ≥150 ms, EF ≤35%, persistent symptoms on GDMT
Consider advanced therapies (LVAD, transplant) for refractory Stage D
pearls: Target doses should be individualized to BP, renal function, and potassium.
Consider iron repletion in iron deficiency (IV preferred in symptomatic HF).
Up‑titrate GDMT every 2–4 weeks toward target doses as tolerated
Reassess BMP/K+ within 1–2 weeks after initiating or uptitrating RAAS/MRA
Repeat TTE 3–6 months after GDMT optimization
Low‑sodium diet, fluid guidance, daily weights; action plan for rapid weight gain
Early post‑discharge follow‑up within 7 days; consider HF disease management program
Ensure 4‑pillar GDMT started or planned (ARNI/ACE/ARB, β‑blocker, MRA, SGLT2i)
Loop diuretic with clear dose/goal and PRN plan
Vaccinations and guideline lipid/BP therapy as indicated
Close follow-up for HF management

diagnoses.name: Hypertension (HTN)
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition characterized by persistently elevated blood pressure (systolic >130 mmHg or diastolic >80 mmHg) that increases cardiovascular risk and can lead to end-organ damage.
features: White coat hypertension: elevated in office but normal at home
Masked hypertension: normal in office but elevated at home
Secondary HTN clues: severe/resistant HTN, age <30, abdominal bruit, hypokalemia
End-organ damage: LVH, retinopathy, CKD, CAD, stroke, PAD
workup: Confirm diagnosis: elevated readings on ≥2 separate occasions [WHY: Single elevated reading insufficient - white coat hypertension affects 15-30%, multiple readings ensure true hypertension]
Out-of-office BP measurement: ambulatory BP monitoring (ABPM) or home BP [WHY: Detects white coat HTN and masked HTN, 24-hour ABPM is gold standard for diagnosis]
Staging: Stage 1 (130-139/80-89), Stage 2 (≥140/≥90) [WHY: Determines treatment urgency - Stage 2 requires immediate dual therapy, Stage 1 may start with lifestyle]
Evaluate for secondary causes if: age <30, resistant HTN, abrupt onset, hypokalemia [WHY: 5-10% of HTN is secondary and potentially curable - early recognition saves lifelong treatment]

Secondary HTN workup: renal artery duplex, plasma renin/aldosterone ratio, 24-hour urine metanephrines [WHY: Identifies specific causes - renal artery stenosis, primary aldosteronism, pheochromocytoma requiring targeted treatment]

Assess end-organ damage: EKG (LVH), echocardiogram, UA (proteinuria), creatinine/eGFR, lipid panel [WHY: End-organ damage indicates need for aggressive treatment, affects cardiovascular risk stratification]
Cardiovascular risk assessment: ASCVD risk calculator [WHY: Guides intensity of treatment - higher risk patients benefit from lower BP targets and statin therapy]
Special populations: diabetics/CKD same target as general (<130/80), age >60 [WHY: Different populations have different risk-benefit profiles for BP targets based on clinical trial evidence]
management: Lifestyle modifications: DASH diet, weight loss, exercise, sodium restriction (<2.3g/day), alcohol moderation
Smoking cessation, stress reduction, adequate sleep
Pharmacologic therapy: Start with monotherapy, titrate every 2-4 weeks
First-line agents: Thiazide diuretics (chlorthalidone), ACEi/ARB, long-acting CCB (amlodipine)
Comorbidity-based selection: Diabetes/CKD (ACEi/ARB), CAD/CHF (beta-blocker/ACEi/ARB), BPH (alpha-blocker)
Stage 2 HTN: Start with 2 agents (usually including diuretic)
Resistant HTN: ≥3 agents including diuretic, consider mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist
BP goals: <130/80 mmHg for most, <130/80 for diabetics/CKD, <150/90 for age >60
Monitor electrolytes, renal function, side effects
Annual follow-up for stable patients, more frequent for uncontrolled
pearls: HTN affects ~45% of US adults, leading cause of CVD mortality
Essential HTN (>95%): idiopathic; Secondary HTN (~5%): renovascular, endocrine, drugs
White coat HTN: 20-30% of diagnosed HTN, lower CV risk than sustained HTN
Resistant HTN: uncontrolled on ≥3 agents including diuretic
Secondary causes: renal artery stenosis (abdominal bruit), hyperaldosteronism (hypokalemia), pheochromocytoma (episodic)
Medication adherence critical - most 'resistant' HTN is non-adherent
Avoid NSAIDs in HTN patients (fluid retention, reduced diuretic efficacy)
Regular BP monitoring at home improves control
Age >60: permissive HTN (>150/90) unless diabetic/CKD
Pregnancy: methyldopa, labetalol, nifedipine; avoid ACEi/ARB

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Emergency
diagnoses.description: Severely elevated blood pressure (usually >180/120) with acute end-organ damage requiring immediate but controlled BP reduction in a monitored setting.
features: Severely elevated BP with acute end-organ damage
Hypertensive encephalopathy: headache, confusion, seizures, coma
Acute aortic dissection: severe chest/back pain, pulse deficits
Acute coronary syndrome: chest pain, dyspnea, diaphoresis
Acute kidney injury: oliguria, elevated creatinine
Pulmonary edema: dyspnea, orthopnea, pink frothy sputum
Patient appears ill, may be in acute distress
workup: Immediate assessment: ABCs, vital signs, neurologic exam [WHY: Hypertensive emergency is life-threatening - assess airway, breathing, circulation and neurologic function to guide immediate interventions]
EKG: rule out ischemia, LV strain, arrhythmias [WHY: Severe hypertension can cause demand ischemia or acute MI, LV strain patterns indicate chronic damage]
Chest X-ray: pulmonary edema, widened mediastinum [WHY: Identifies heart failure from severe HTN, widened mediastinum suggests aortic dissection requiring different treatment]
Labs: CBC, BMP, troponin, UA, lactate [WHY: Assesses end-organ damage - kidney function (creatinine), cardiac damage (troponin), tissue perfusion (lactate)]
CT/MRI brain if neurologic symptoms [WHY: Rules out stroke vs hypertensive encephalopathy - stroke contraindicates rapid BP lowering]
CT angiogram if aortic dissection suspected [WHY: Aortic dissection requires immediate surgery and different BP targets than other hypertensive emergencies]
Echocardiogram if cardiac involvement [WHY: Assesses for acute heart failure, wall motion abnormalities from ischemia, aortic regurgitation from dissection]
Fundoscopic exam for papilledema [WHY: Optic disc swelling confirms severe end-organ damage, helps differentiate emergency from urgency]
Pregnancy test in women of childbearing age [WHY: Eclampsia/preeclampsia requires different management - magnesium sulfate, delivery planning]
management: Immediate but controlled BP reduction in ICU setting
First 2 hours: reduce by ~20% of target
First 24 hours: reduce by ~35% of target
Avoid >30% reduction in first few hours
Choice of agent based on clinical scenario:
Aortic dissection: IV beta-blocker (labetalol/esmolol) + nitroprusside, target SBP <120
ACS: nitroglycerin + beta-blocker, avoid nitroprusside
Encephalopathy: labetalol or nicardipine
Pulmonary edema: nitroglycerin + loop diuretic
Eclampsia: magnesium sulfate + hydralazine or labetalol
Continuous BP monitoring, frequent neurologic checks
Transition to oral agents when stable
Address underlying causes and long-term management
pearls: Emergency = end-organ damage present, Urgency = no end-organ damage
Too rapid BP reduction can cause ischemia/worsening
Aortic dissection: reduce SBP <120 within 20 minutes
Stroke: keep SBP <185/110 if thrombolysis/cath planned
No single first-line agent - choice depends on presentation
ICU admission required for all emergencies
Continuous IV infusion preferred for precise control
Transition to oral agents when patient stable
Long-term follow-up essential to prevent recurrence
Identify and treat underlying causes (medication non-adherence, secondary HTN)

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Urgency / Emergency
diagnoses.description: Severely elevated blood pressure with or without acute end-organ damage.
workup: Focused exam for end-organ damage (neuro, cardio-pulm)
BMP, UA
ECG ± troponin
CXR if pulmonary edema; Head CT if neuro deficits; Fundoscopy if concern for retinal hemorrhages
management: Differentiate **Urgency** (no end-organ damage) vs **Emergency** (with damage)
Urgency: oral agents, gradual reduction over 24–48h, close follow-up
Emergency: ICU, IV meds; lower MAP ~10–20% in first hour, then additional 5–15% over next 23h (avoid rapid over-correction)
Nicardipine, clevidipine, labetalol, esmolol, nitroprusside (monitor cyanide/thiocyanate), nitroglycerin (esp. ACS/pulmonary edema), hydralazine (selected settings, e.g., pregnancy)
Aortic dissection: reduce HR/BP rapidly with β-blocker + vasodilator (SBP <120, HR <60)
Ischemic stroke: follow thrombolysis/EVT BP thresholds
Preeclampsia/eclampsia: labetalol, hydralazine, or nifedipine; magnesium for seizure prophylaxis
pearls: Avoid precipitous BP drops that risk cerebral/coronary ischemia
ACEi/ARB/ARNI contraindicated in pregnancy
Close outpatient follow-up within days after urgency; ensure long-term regimen optimization

diagnoses.name: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition causing abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, potentially leading to obstruction and arrhythmias.
workup: Echo (asymmetric septal hypertrophy, systolic anterior motion of mitral valve, dynamic LVOT gradient)
ECG (LVH, repolarization abnormalities)
Holter/event monitor (arrhythmias)
Cardiac MRI for morphology/fibrosis
Genetic testing in selected patients
management: β-blockers (first-line) or non-DHP CCBs (verapamil, diltiazem)
Avoid dehydration, excessive exertion, vasodilators, diuretics (↓ preload)
ICD if prior cardiac arrest, sustained VT, or high-risk features
Septal reduction (surgical myectomy or alcohol ablation) if refractory symptoms with gradient
Transplant if end-stage HF
pearls: Annual echo if symptomatic or every 1–2y if stable
Family screening with echo/ECG
Cardiology/HCM specialist follow-up

diagnoses.name: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)
diagnoses.description: Genetic cardiac muscle disease characterized by myocardial hypertrophy in the absence of hemodynamic stress, often with asymmetric septal hypertrophy.
features: Family history of sudden cardiac death
May be asymptomatic in early stages

signs_any: Harsh systolic murmur at LSB/apex, ↑ with Valsalva, ↓ with squatting

workup: Echocardiogram: Diagnostic test of choice [WHY: Shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy, SAM, dynamic LVOT obstruction]
Key findings: septal thickness ≥15mm, systolic anterior motion of mitral valve
ECG: Often abnormal [WHY: Shows LVH with repolarization abnormalities, helps identify high-risk features]
Findings: LVH, deep Q waves, T-wave inversions, atrial enlargement
Holter/event monitoring: Assess for arrhythmias [WHY: VT/VF detection guides ICD therapy decisions]
Exercise stress testing: Evaluate symptoms and blood pressure response [WHY: Abnormal BP response indicates higher risk]
Cardiac MRI: Advanced imaging [WHY: Better tissue characterization, identifies fibrosis, guides risk stratification]
Cardiac catheterization: If LVOT gradient unclear [WHY: Provocative maneuvers can unmask dynamic obstruction]
Genetic testing: Recommended for probands [WHY: Identifies specific mutations, guides family screening]
Family screening: First-degree relatives [WHY: 50% inheritance rate, early detection prevents sudden death]
management: β-blockers: First-line therapy [WHY: Reduces LVOT gradient, improves diastolic filling, controls arrhythmias]
Preferred: metoprolol, propranolol, atenolol
Non-dihydropyridine CCBs: Alternative therapy [WHY: Verapamil/diltiazem improve diastolic function]
Disopyramide: For refractory LVOT obstruction [WHY: Negative inotrope reduces gradient]
ICD therapy: High-risk patients [WHY: Prevents sudden cardiac death in high-risk features]
Indications: prior cardiac arrest, sustained VT, family history of SCD, massive LVH (≥30mm)
Septal reduction therapy: Refractory symptoms with significant gradient
Options: surgical myectomy (gold standard) or alcohol septal ablation
Activity restrictions: Avoid competitive sports, high-intensity exercise
Genetic counseling: For patients and families

avoid_medications: Diuretics (unless volume overloaded) - reduce preload, worsen gradient
Dihydropyridine CCBs (nifedipine, amlodipine) - vasodilation worsens gradient

pearls: Most common genetic cardiovascular disease (1:500 prevalence)
Autosomal dominant inheritance - 50% of offspring affected
Leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes
Murmur increases with Valsalva, decreases with squatting (opposite of most murmurs)
Symptoms often develop in adolescence or young adulthood
Pregnancy generally well-tolerated with proper management
Annual cardiology follow-up recommended for all patients
Family screening should continue every 3-5 years until age 50+
Consider advanced heart failure therapies if develops systolic dysfunction
