diagnoses.name: Hypovolemic Shock
diagnoses.description: Shock due to inadequate circulating blood volume from blood loss or plasma loss.
features: Reflex tachycardia, hypotension with narrow pulse pressure
Altered mental status, oliguria, delayed capillary refill
Blood plasma loss: GI (vomiting, diarrhea), skin (burns, diaphoresis), renal (diuretics)
Blood loss: Trauma, GI bleeding, AAA rupture, postpartum hemorrhage, surgical bleeding
workup: CBC: Hemoglobin trend (drop from baseline), platelet count
BUN/Cr ratio: >20:1 suggests prerenal AKI from volume depletion
Lactate: >2 mmol/L indicates tissue hypoperfusion
Swan-Ganz findings: ↓CVP (<5 mmHg), ↓PCWP (<12 mmHg), ↓CI, ↑SVR, ↓SvO2
Source identification: CT imaging, endoscopy, surgical exploration as indicated
management: IV access: 2 large bore IVs, type and crossmatch
Crystalloid resuscitation: Normal saline or LR, initial 20-30 mL/kg bolus
Blood products: PRBCs if Hgb <7 g/dL or symptomatic, FFP/platelets if coagulopathy
Source control: Endoscopy (GI bleed), surgery (trauma), interventional procedures
Monitoring: Continuous vitals, urine output >0.5 mL/kg/hr, serial Hgb and lactate
pearls: Avoid excessive fluid in concomitant heart failure
Blood transfusion goal Hgb >7 g/dL (>10 g/dL if active CAD)
Massive transfusion protocol: 1:1:1 ratio PRBC:FFP:Platelets
Early source control prevents ongoing losses
Documentation: 'Hemoglobin dropped from 12.1 to 8.3 g/dL, concerning for ongoing blood loss'

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: Infection of the endocardial surface of the heart that extends to the heart valves. Risk factors include valvular heart disease, congenital heart disease, prosthetic heart valves, immunosuppression, age over 60, injection drug use.
features: Janeway lesions (painless plaques on palms and soles)
Osler nodes (painful nodules on fingers and toes)
Roth spots (pale retinal lesions with hemorrhage)
workup: Blood cultures: Three sets, separated by one hour, before starting antibiotics [WHY: 95% sensitive when done properly, timing separation increases yield, must obtain before antibiotics destroy organisms]
Echocardiogram: TTE initial, TEE if negative or complications suspected [WHY: TTE only 60% sensitive for vegetations, TEE 95% sensitive - detects abscesses, perforations, extent of valve damage]
CBC, ESR/CRP, renal function [WHY: CBC shows leukocytosis/anemia, ESR/CRP track treatment response, renal function guides antibiotic dosing]
CXR if pulmonary symptoms (right-sided IE) [WHY: Right-sided endocarditis causes septic pulmonary emboli - multiple bilateral infiltrates on CXR]
Duke Criteria for diagnosis [WHY: Standardized criteria combining clinical, microbiologic, and echocardiographic findings for accurate diagnosis]
Definitive: 2 major, or 1 major + 3 minor, or 5 minor criteria
Major: Positive blood culture, echocardiographic evidence, new regurgitant murmur
Minor: Predisposition, fever, vascular phenomena, immunologic phenomena, positive cultures not meeting major
Colonoscopy if Streptococcus bovis or Clostridium septicum [WHY: Strong association with colon cancer - up to 25% of patients have malignancy requiring screening]
management: Start empiric therapy: Ceftriaxone or vancomycin + gentamicin until cultures return
Tailor antibiotics to culture results for 4-6 weeks IV therapy
Common organisms: Streptococcus viridans (native valves), Staphylococcus aureus (IV drug users), Coagulase-negative staph (prosthetic valves)
HACEK organisms: Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella (require 5 days culture)
Surgery if heart failure, uncontrolled infection, large vegetations with emboli, abscess
Anticoagulation generally avoided in acute IE with CNS emboli (hemorrhage risk)
Monitor renal function, drug levels (aminoglycosides, vancomycin)
pearls: Prophylaxis with amoxicillin indicated for:
- History of endocarditis
- Prosthetic valves
- Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease
- Cardiac transplant with valvulopathy
Procedures requiring prophylaxis: Dental (gingival), respiratory invasive, skin infection treatment
Repeat blood cultures to document clearance
Monitor for complications: Heart failure, emboli, abscess, conduction abnormalities
Adherence to prolonged IV antibiotic therapy (often via PICC)
Report fevers, embolic symptoms, new murmurs
Dental hygiene critical to reduce recurrence risk
Infectious disease and cardiology co-management
Consider outpatient parenteral antibiotic therapy (OPAT) when stable

diagnoses.name: Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB)
diagnoses.description: Electrical activity in the left bundle branch is slowed, causing delayed activation of the left ventricle.
features: Associated with hypertension, coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy
May progress to complete heart block
workup: 12-lead ECG: Wide QRS (>0.12 sec), notched R wave in I/aVL/V5/V6, absent Q wave in I/V5/V6
ST/T wave displacement opposite to QRS deflection
Echocardiogram to assess LV function and wall motion
Coronary angiography if ischemia suspected
Cardiac MRI for infiltrative or inflammatory disease
Electrophysiology study if conduction disease suspected
Holter monitor for intermittent LBBB
management: Treat underlying cardiac disease (HTN, CAD, cardiomyopathy)
New LBBB in ACS setting: Treat as STEMI equivalent
Pacemaker consideration for symptomatic bradycardia or heart failure
CRT consideration if LBBB + reduced EF + heart failure symptoms
Beta-blockers for rate control if tachycardia-induced
Address reversible causes (electrolytes, ischemia)
Regular monitoring for progression to advanced AV block
pearls: New LBBB = STEMI equivalent - activate cath lab immediately
LBBB can mask anterolateral STEMI - look for concordant ST changes
LBBB + RBBB = complete heart block
LBBB with wide QRS may indicate ventricular tachycardia
Associated with dilated cardiomyopathy and aortic stenosis
May improve with treatment of underlying disease
CRT improves outcomes in LBBB with reduced EF
Serial ECGs to monitor for resolution or progression

diagnoses.name: Long QT Syndrome (LQTS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the heart's electrical system that can cause fast, chaotic heartbeats.
workup: 12-lead ECG (QT interval measurement)
Holter/event monitor if intermittent
Family history, genetic testing if congenital LQTS suspected
Labs: electrolytes, thyroid, drug screen
management: Avoid QT-prolonging drugs (macrolides, fluoroquinolones, antiarrhythmics, antipsychotics, methadone, etc.)
Correct electrolyte abnormalities (K+, Mg2+, Ca2+)
β-blockers (nadolol, propranolol) for congenital LQTS
ICD if history of cardiac arrest, recurrent syncope/VT despite β-blocker
Left cardiac sympathetic denervation in refractory cases
IV magnesium sulfate for Torsades de Pointes
Overdrive pacing or isoproterenol if bradycardic
pearls: Adherence to β-blocker therapy
Avoid QT-prolonging drugs (provide list)
Family screening for congenital forms
Electrophysiology/genetics follow-up

diagnoses.name: MitraClip (Post-Operative Care by NP)
diagnoses.description: Post-operative care following MitraClip transcatheter edge-to-edge repair procedure for mitral regurgitation.
features: Evaluation of cardiac status and symptoms
Monitoring for pericardial effusion or tamponade
workup: ECHO: Post-op day 1; discharge after ECHO is complete and no pericardial effusion present
Monitoring: Groin sites, peripheral pulses
Vital signs assessment
Pain assessment at access sites
Cardiac rhythm monitoring
management: Anticoagulation: Managed by operating physician
Pain management at groin sites
Mobilization as tolerated
Diet advancement as appropriate
Patient education on activity restrictions
Follow-up appointment scheduling
Discharge planning coordination
pearls: Monitor for signs of infection at access sites
Assess for post-procedure complications (tamponade, stroke, vascular injury)
Ensure adequate pain control before discharge
Patient education on medication adherence and follow-up
Coordinate with cardiology team for ongoing care
Document baseline ECHO findings for comparison

diagnoses.name: Mitral Regurgitation
diagnoses.description: Backflow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium due to mitral valve insufficiency.
features: Etiologies: Mitral valve prolapse, coronary artery disease
Symptoms: Dyspnea, fatigue, syncope (often asymptomatic early)
Murmur: Holosystolic murmur at the apex, radiating to axilla
workup: Transthoracic echo (jet severity, LA/LV size, function, mechanism)
TEE if needed for mechanism/surgical planning
ECG (AF, LA enlargement)
CXR (cardiomegaly, pulmonary congestion)
management: Treatment: Asymptomatic → observation; Symptomatic → vasodilators; Surgery if severe or progressive
Treat HTN, AF, and heart failure symptoms
Afterload reduction (ACEi/ARB, vasodilators) in acute or symptomatic MR if not immediately surgical
Symptomatic severe MR or LVEF ≤60% or LVESD ≥40 mm → mitral surgery (repair preferred over replacement)
Acute severe MR (papillary rupture, chordal rupture, endocarditis): urgent surgery
MitraClip (TEER) for selected patients not surgical candidates
pearls: Use cautiously in preload-dependent patients with acute MR and hypotension
Echo surveillance: mild q3–5y, moderate q1–2y, severe q6–12mo
Report new or worsening dyspnea, edema, or palpitations
Maintain dental hygiene to reduce endocarditis risk
Cardiology/valve clinic follow-up per severity
Acute MR from papillary muscle rupture is surgical emergency
Chronic MR may be asymptomatic for years

diagnoses.name: Mitral Stenosis
diagnoses.description: Narrowing of the mitral valve opening, restricting blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle.
features: Symptoms: Dyspnea, orthopnea, atrial fibrillation, hemoptysis; symptoms exacerbated in pregnancy
Murmur: Low-pitched diastolic rumble at apex
workup: Transthoracic echo (valve area, mean gradient, LA size, pulmonary pressures)
ECG (LA enlargement, AF common)
CXR (LA enlargement, pulmonary congestion)
management: Treatment: Balloon valvotomy or surgery; diuretics and beta blockers for symptom control
Diuretics for pulmonary congestion
Rate control (β-blocker, diltiazem, digoxin) if AF
Anticoagulation if AF, prior embolism, or LA thrombus
Percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy if suitable anatomy
Surgical repair/replacement if not suitable or concurrent valve disease
pearls: Careful management; balloon valvotomy considered if severe symptoms
Echo q3–5y (mild), q1–2y (moderate), annually (severe)
Report new-onset dyspnea, palpitations, or hemoptysis
Endocarditis prophylaxis only in select prosthetic/high-risk cases
Cardiology follow-up per severity and rhythm status
Pregnancy worsens symptoms due to increased cardiac output
Monitor for progression to atrial fibrillation

diagnoses.name: Mitral Valve Prolapse
diagnoses.description: Prolapse of one or both mitral valve leaflets into the left atrium during systole.
features: Symptoms: Usually asymptomatic; may have chest pain, palpitations, anxiety
Murmur: Mid-systolic click with a possible late systolic murmur (severity dependent)
workup: Transthoracic echo (leaflet prolapse, regurgitation severity, chordal rupture)
ECG (nonspecific changes, arrhythmias)
Holter monitoring if palpitations
management: Treatment: Beta blockers
Asymptomatic: reassurance and follow-up
Symptomatic: beta-blockers for palpitations, chest pain
Anticoagulation if AF or prior embolic event
Surgical repair if severe MR develops
pearls: Most patients asymptomatic and require no treatment
Regular echo surveillance for progression to MR
Beta-blockers effective for symptoms
Endocarditis prophylaxis not routinely recommended
Family screening may be considered

diagnoses.name: Myocarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the heart muscle, often due to viral infection.
workup: Troponin
ECG
Echo
Cardiac MRI
Endomyocardial biopsy (select)
management: Supportive HF therapy
Avoid NSAIDs/ETOH
Immunosuppression if giant cell/autoimmune
Mechanical support, transplant if refractory
pearls: No exercise until cleared
Cardiology

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Shock
diagnoses.description: Shock due to mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling or outflow.
features: JVD (elevated central venous pressure), reflex tachycardia
Cardiac tamponade: Beck's triad (JVD, muffled heart sounds, hypotension), pulsus paradoxus >10 mmHg
Tension pneumothorax: Absent breath sounds, hyperresonance, tracheal deviation
Massive PE: Dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia, hypoxemia, S1Q3T3 pattern
workup: Swan-Ganz findings: ↑CVP (>15 mmHg), ↓PCWP (except tamponade), ↓CI, ↑SVR, ↓SvO2
Tamponade: Echo (pericardial effusion, RV collapse), ECG (low voltage, electrical alternans)
Tension PTX: CXR (complete lung collapse, mediastinal shift), clinical diagnosis
Massive PE: CT-PE, V/Q scan, elevated D-dimer, Echo (RV strain)
management: Tamponade: Emergency pericardiocentesis (even small drainage improves hemodynamics)
Tension PTX: Immediate needle thoracostomy → chest tube placement
Massive PE: Anticoagulation + thrombolytics (tPA 100 mg over 2 hours) or embolectomy
General: Treat underlying cause immediately, maintain preload, avoid excessive PPV
Supportive: Oxygen, vasopressors after source control
pearls: Pericardiocentesis contraindications: Aortic dissection with hemopericardium
Thrombolytic contraindications: Active bleeding, recent surgery, intracranial pathology
Avoid fluid overload in RV strain from massive PE
Emergency procedures save lives - don't delay for imaging if unstable
Documentation: 'Beck's triad present, concerning for cardiac tamponade'

diagnoses.name: Orthostatic Hypotension
diagnoses.description: Occurs due to autonomic dysfunction and is an inadequate physiological response to postural changes. More common in patients >65 years.
workup: Measure BP lying down → then after standing for 2 minutes
Diagnosis: systolic drop ≥20 mmHg or diastolic drop ≥10 mmHg
Tilt table testing if suspicion remains despite normal vitals
Orthostatic vital signs: Document HR and BP lying, sitting, standing
Measure at 2-minute intervals
Assess for underlying causes (medications, hypovolemia, anemia, etc.)
management: Address underlying cause
Have patients rise slowly from supine to standing (especially in mornings)
Increase fluid and sodium intake
If persistent: fludrocortisone (mineralocorticoid) is first-line therapy
Compression stockings
Medication review and adjustment
Physical therapy for strengthening exercises
pearls: Common in elderly patients
Review medications for hypotensive agents
Encourage adequate hydration
Teach patients to change positions slowly
Monitor for falls and injury prevention
Consider referral to cardiology if autonomic dysfunction suspected

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT)
diagnoses.description: Intermittent, abrupt-onset supraventricular tachycardias originating above the ventricles, most commonly AV nodal reentry or AV reentry.
features: Sudden onset and termination of palpitations
Shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness
Altered mental status or hypotension if prolonged
May be triggered by caffeine, stress, or exercise
History of similar episodes in past
workup: 12-lead ECG during episode: Narrow complex tachycardia, regular rhythm
Holter monitor or event recorder for documentation
Echocardiogram to rule out structural heart disease
Electrolyte panel and thyroid function
Consider EPS for recurrent or refractory cases
Exercise stress testing to reproduce symptoms
Carotid massage or Valsalva under monitoring (diagnostic)
management: Acute termination: Vagal maneuvers (Valsalva, carotid massage)
Adenosine 6mg IV push (first-line pharmacologic)
If adenosine ineffective: Diltiazem or metoprolol IV
Unstable patients: Immediate synchronized cardioversion
Chronic prevention: Beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin
Antiarrhythmic drugs: Flecainide, propafenone for refractory cases
Catheter ablation (curative) for recurrent symptomatic PSVT
Patient education about vagal maneuvers and trigger avoidance
pearls: Adenosine is diagnostic and therapeutic for SVT vs VT
Vagal maneuvers successful in 20-30% of cases
PSVT rarely degenerates to VF (unlike VT)
WPW patients may develop rapid AF through accessory pathway
Avoid verapamil in WPW (may accelerate ventricular rate)
Ablation success rate >95% for AVNRT and AVRT
Recurrent PSVT may indicate underlying SVT substrate
Holter monitoring helpful for asymptomatic episodes

diagnoses.name: Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
diagnoses.description: Persistence of the ductus arteriosus beyond the first 24 hours of life, causing abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery.
features: Moderate PDA: wide pulse pressure, bounding pulses, continuous machine-like murmur
Large PDA: heart failure, poor growth, frequent respiratory infections
Preterm infants: predisposed due to pulmonary compromise
Physical exam: continuous murmur throughout systole and diastole
Best heard at left infraclavicular area
Differential cyanosis (pink upper body, blue lower body) in severe cases
workup: Echocardiogram: ductal anatomy, shunt magnitude, pulmonary pressures
Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascularity
ECG: LVH, LAE if large shunt
CTA: most accurate test for ductal anatomy
Labs: BNP elevated in heart failure
management: Infancy: Keep PDA open with prostaglandins if dependent on PDA (TOF, TGA, hypoplastic left heart, pulmonary atresia)
Premature infants: indomethacin/ibuprofen to close PDA
Term infants: percutaneous catheter closure or surgical ligation
Device closure: preferred method if suitable anatomy
Medical management: diuretics, ACEi for heart failure symptoms
Pulmonary hypertension management if present
Endocarditis prophylaxis: 6 months post-closure
pearls: Ductus arteriosus normally closes within first 24 hours due to rising oxygen levels
Prostaglandins maintain patency, indomethacin/ibuprofen promote closure
Qp:Qs ratio >1.5 indicates significant shunt requiring closure
Serial echocardiograms to monitor ductal size and pulmonary pressures
Risk of pulmonary hypertension if untreated
Device closure has lower complication rate than surgery
Report dyspnea, poor feeding, recurrent infections, or cyanosis
Lifelong cardiology follow-up
Pregnancy generally well-tolerated but requires monitoring

diagnoses.name: Pericardial Effusion / Tamponade
diagnoses.description: Excess pericardial fluid exerts pressure on the heart → restricted filling and hemodynamic compromise.
features: Beck's Triad: hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins
Pulsus paradoxus (decrease in SBP >10 mmHg during inspiration)
workup: EKG: electrical alternans (QRS complexes alternate in amplitude)
Chest X-ray: enlarged cardiac silhouette, clear lung fields
Echocardiogram: pericardial effusion, diastolic collapse of right-sided chambers
Definitive diagnosis and treatment: pericardiocentesis
management: Immediate pericardiocentesis or surgical drainage
Volume resuscitation if hypotensive
Treat underlying cause (malignancy, infection, autoimmune, trauma)
Monitor for recurrence
Serial echocardiograms post-drainage
pearls: Serial echo after drainage
Monitor for recurrence depending on etiology
Report syncope, hypotension, or worsening dyspnea immediately
Medication adherence (if autoimmune/inflammatory)
Cardiology follow-up; oncology/rheum/nephrology if secondary cause
Urgent intervention required - do not delay pericardiocentesis
Consider tamponade in any patient with pericardial effusion + hypotension

diagnoses.name: Perioperative Medication Management
diagnoses.description: Guidelines for managing cardiovascular medications around the time of surgery (Adapted from CIS Guidelines – Preoperative Risk Assessment, updated 9/27/18).
features: Key point: Although adapted for outpatient settings, this policy can be applied to acute care with physician collaboration
Individualized decision-making based on thrombosis vs bleeding risk
Collaboration between surgeon, cardiologist, and anesthesiologist essential
Consider procedure-specific bleeding risk and patient comorbidities
workup: Assess CHA₂DS₂-VASc score for atrial fibrillation patients on anticoagulation
Evaluate coronary stent type and timing (DES vs BMS)
Determine procedure bleeding risk (low, intermediate, high)
Review recent cardiac events or interventions
Assess renal function for DOAC dosing
Check for drug interactions affecting perioperative management
management: Anticoagulants:
Xarelto/Eliquis/Savaysa/Pradaxa: Hold 24–48 hrs pre-op; restart 24–48 hrs post-op (decision made by surgeon & cardiologist)
Coumadin for A-fib: If CHA₂DS₂-VASc ≤4 and no history of ischemic CVA/TIA → hold 4–5 days, depending on INR; recheck INR within 24 hrs pre-op
Coumadin for A-fib: If CHA₂DS₂-VASc ≥5 or history of ischemic CVA/TIA → consider bridging (decision individualized)
Coumadin for Mechanical Valve: Bridge unless procedure is very low risk; decision individualized
Coumadin for DVT/PE: Bridge unless recent CVA/AVR
Aspirin: Hold 5–7 days pre-op unless contraindicated
Antiplatelets (Clopidogrel, Effient, Brilinta) - Coronary stents:
DES <12 months: Delay elective surgery if possible. If non-cardiac surgery required, evaluate thrombosis risk (especially with multivessel CAD, CHF, DM)
BMS <1 month: Delay surgery if possible
DES >12 months: May hold antiplatelet for 7 days with surgeon approval
Antiplatelets - Peripheral stents: 3 months: Hold antiplatelet for 7 days pre-op and resume post-op per surgeon approval
Antiplatelets - Peripheral stents: <3 months: Defer surgery if possible
pearls: Balance thrombosis risk vs bleeding risk for each patient
Document perioperative medication plan in medical record
Clear communication between all providers involved
Consider heparin bridging for high thrombosis risk patients
Resume full anticoagulation regimen as soon as hemostasis achieved
Monitor for post-operative bleeding complications
Involve cardiology for complex anticoagulation management
Patient education regarding medication changes and resumption timing

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD)
diagnoses.description: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) commonly coexists with coronary artery disease. Narrowing of the peripheral arteries, reducing blood flow to the limbs.
features: Classic presentation: angina of the legs (pain with exertion, relieved with rest)
Claudication (exertional leg pain relieved by rest)
May also show: pallor, ulcers, diminished pulses, hair loss
workup: Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI): Ratio of BP in ankle to BP in arm
Positive test if ABI <0.9 (ankle BP lower than arm BP)
Ankle-brachial index (ABI): PAD if ≤0.90
Toe-brachial index for diabetics or non-compressible vessels
Exercise ABI if symptoms and normal resting ABI
Duplex ultrasound for anatomic assessment; CTA/MRA when planning revascularization
management: Medical: Aspirin, BP/lipid/glucose control (as in CAD)
First step in treatment: Supervised 12-week exercise regimen
Medication: Cilostazol (only drug shown to provide medical benefit in PAD)
Smoking cessation
High-intensity statin
Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or clopidogrel)
Optimize BP, diabetes; consider SGLT2i/GLP-1 RA for CV benefit in DM
Cilostazol improves walking distance (avoid in HFrEF)
Endovascular or surgical revascularization for lifestyle-limiting claudication refractory to therapy or critical limb-threatening ischemia
pearls: Foot care education, wound surveillance in high-risk patients
ABI surveillance after revascularization per protocol
Daily foot inspection, protective footwear
Adherence to exercise therapy and medications
Vascular/cardiology follow-up; wound care as needed

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma / Paraganglioma
diagnoses.description: Tumors that arise from the adrenal gland tissue and cause excess production of catecholamines.
workup: Plasma free metanephrines (preferred screening)
24h urine catecholamines/metanephrines
CT/MRI abdomen-pelvis for localization
MIBG or PET for metastatic/extra-adrenal disease
management: α-blockade (phenoxybenzamine or doxazosin) 7–14d before surgery
Then add β-blocker after α-blockade if tachycardia
Surgical resection (laparoscopic adrenalectomy if adrenal)
pearls: Never start β-blocker before α-blockade — risk hypertensive crisis
Medication adherence pre-surgery
Report headaches, palpitations, diaphoresis
Endocrinology follow-up, genetic counseling for familial cases

diagnoses.name: Premature Atrial Contraction (PAC)
diagnoses.description: Ectopic beats originating from the atria outside the SA node, causing early atrial depolarization.
features: Often asymptomatic or felt as skipped beats
Associated with caffeine, stress, alcohol, smoking
May be frequent or occur in patterns
More common with age and comorbidities
workup: 12-lead ECG: Early P wave with different morphology, may be non-conducted
Holter monitor to quantify PAC burden
Echocardiogram to rule out structural heart disease
Thyroid function and electrolyte panel
Consider sleep study if nocturnal PACs
Exercise testing to assess autonomic tone
Event monitor for symptom correlation
management: Asymptomatic PACs: No treatment required
Symptomatic PACs: Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers
Frequent PACs: Address underlying causes (caffeine, stress)
Antiarrhythmic therapy for refractory cases
Lifestyle modifications: Reduce stimulants, improve sleep
Rate/rhythm control if PACs trigger AF
Regular monitoring for progression to sustained arrhythmias
Patient education about benign nature
pearls: PACs are common and usually benign
Frequent PACs (>100/hour) may predict AF development
PACs can be suppressed by vagal maneuvers
Associated with hypertension, sleep apnea, obesity
May be first sign of digitalis toxicity
Exercise can increase PAC frequency in some patients
No specific PVC burden threshold for treatment
Monitor for atrial fibrillation development

diagnoses.name: Premature Ventricular Contraction (PVC)
diagnoses.description: Ectopic beats originating from the ventricles, interrupting the normal cardiac rhythm.
features: Often asymptomatic, felt as skipped beats
Associated with caffeine, stress, electrolyte abnormalities
workup: 12-lead ECG: Wide QRS without preceding P wave, compensatory pause
Holter monitor to quantify PVC burden
Echocardiogram to assess cardiac structure and function
Exercise stress testing to evaluate ischemia
Electrolyte panel and thyroid function
Consider cardiac MRI if cardiomyopathy suspected
24-hour ambulatory monitoring for correlation with symptoms
management: Benign PVCs (<1000/day, asymptomatic): No treatment
Symptomatic PVCs: Beta-blockers (metoprolol, propranolol)
Frequent PVCs (>10% of beats): Antiarrhythmics (amiodarone, mexiletine)
Address underlying causes (electrolytes, ischemia, drugs)
Catheter ablation for refractory symptomatic PVCs
Lifestyle modifications: Reduce caffeine, stress, alcohol
ICD consideration if PVCs trigger VT/VF
Regular follow-up to monitor PVC burden and symptoms
pearls: PVC burden >10% associated with PVC-induced cardiomyopathy
R-on-T PVCs increase sudden death risk
PVCs common in healthy individuals (1-4% of beats)
Exercise suppresses PVCs in healthy hearts
Frequent PVCs may indicate occult coronary disease
Ablation success rate >80% for symptomatic PVCs
Beta-blockers first-line for symptomatic PVCs
Monitor for QT prolongation with antiarrhythmic therapy

diagnoses.name: Primary Aldosteronism
diagnoses.description: A condition of excessive aldosterone secretion, leading to hypertension and electrolyte imbalances.
workup: Plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) / plasma renin activity (PRA) ratio (screening)
Confirmatory tests: saline suppression, oral salt loading, fludrocortisone suppression
Adrenal CT to localize adenoma vs hyperplasia
Adrenal vein sampling if surgery considered
management: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy for unilateral adenoma
Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (spironolactone, eplerenone) for bilateral hyperplasia
pearls: Medication adherence if MRA prescribed
Report gynecomastia, hyperkalemia (spironolactone side effects)
Endocrinology and cardiology follow-up

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
diagnoses.description: Blockage of the pulmonary arteries by blood clots, fat, or air bubbles.
workup: Wells or Geneva score [WHY: Risk stratifies patients - low risk can be ruled out with D-dimer alone, avoiding unnecessary radiation and contrast exposure]
D-dimer (rule out in low/intermediate risk) [WHY: High sensitivity but low specificity - negative D-dimer in low-risk patients safely rules out PE]
CT pulmonary angiography (diagnostic) [WHY: Gold standard test - directly visualizes clots in pulmonary arteries, assesses RV strain and clot burden]
V/Q scan if CTA contraindicated [WHY: Alternative when contrast allergy, pregnancy, or renal dysfunction - uses ventilation/perfusion mismatch to detect PE]
Echo for RV strain if massive/submassive [WHY: RV dysfunction predicts poor outcomes and guides decision for thrombolysis vs embolectomy]
management: DOAC preferred if not contraindicated
LMWH in pregnancy or cancer
Systemic thrombolysis (alteplase) if shock/hemodynamic collapse and no contraindications
Catheter-directed thrombolysis or surgical embolectomy if thrombolysis contraindicated/failed
Anticoagulation mainstay in submassive PE; Thrombolysis considered if worsening RV dysfunction or clinical decline
pearls: Recent major surgery, hemorrhagic stroke, active bleeding: contraindications to thrombolysis
Medication adherence to anticoagulation
Report bleeding, recurrent chest pain/dyspnea
Encourage ambulation as tolerated
Hematology/pulmonology follow-up; duration based on provoked vs unprovoked

thrombolysis: Recent major surgery, hemorrhagic stroke, active bleeding

follow_up: Hematology/pulmonology follow-up; duration based on provoked vs unprovoked

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: Increased blood pressure in the pulmonary arteries, leading to dyspnea and other symptoms.
workup: Echo (RVSP)
RHC (gold standard)
CT chest, V/Q scan for cause
management: Diuretics, O2, anticoagulation in CTEPH
Endothelin receptor antagonists, PDE5 inhibitors, prostacyclin analogs
pearls: Report syncope, edema
Pulmonary HTN specialist

diagnoses.name: Pulmonic Regurgitation
diagnoses.description: Backflow of blood from the pulmonary artery into the right ventricle due to pulmonary valve insufficiency.
workup: Transthoracic echo (regurgitation severity, RV size/function)
ECG (RVH if severe)
CXR (pulmonary artery enlargement)
management: Treat underlying pulmonary hypertension
Surgical replacement if severe symptomatic PR
Regular monitoring for RV dysfunction
pearls: Often well-tolerated for years
Monitor RV function closely
Surgical intervention rare
Associated with pulmonary hypertension
Echo surveillance based on severity

diagnoses.name: Pulmonic Stenosis
diagnoses.description: Narrowing of the pulmonary valve opening, restricting blood flow from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery.
features: Murmur: systolic, best heard at left upper sternal border
workup: Transthoracic echo (valve gradient, RV hypertrophy, pulmonary pressures)
ECG (RVH)
CXR (post-stenotic dilation of pulmonary artery)
management: Balloon valvuloplasty for significant stenosis
Surgical valvotomy if balloon unsuccessful
Regular follow-up for progression
Endocarditis prophylaxis
pearls: Often asymptomatic until severe
Balloon valvuloplasty first-line treatment
Monitor for RV dysfunction
Associated with Noonan syndrome, Tetralogy of Fallot
Regular echo surveillance

diagnoses.name: Pulmonic Valve Disease
diagnoses.description: Diseases affecting the pulmonic valve, including stenosis and regurgitation.
workup: Transthoracic echo (valve morphology, gradients, regurgitant jet, RV size/function)
ECG (RVH, RA enlargement)
CXR (pulmonary artery dilation, RV enlargement)
management: Balloon valvuloplasty for symptomatic severe PS (or asymptomatic severe with RV dysfunction)
Surgery if not suitable for balloon or with other lesions
Treat underlying pulmonary HTN
Valve replacement if severe PR with RV dilation/dysfunction and symptoms
pearls: Serial echo for moderate/severe lesions, RV size/function monitoring
Report exertional dyspnea, edema, syncope
Maintain dental hygiene (endocarditis risk if prosthetic valve)
Cardiology/congenital specialist follow-up depending on etiology

diagnoses.name: Renal Artery Stenosis (RAS)
diagnoses.description: Narrowing of one or both renal arteries, reducing blood flow to the kidneys.
workup: Renal duplex Doppler ultrasound (screening)
CTA or MRA (noninvasive anatomic imaging)
Renal angiography (gold standard, usually for intervention)
management: ACEi/ARB (cautiously, monitor creatinine)
Statins, antiplatelets, BP control, smoking cessation
Angioplasty ± stent in select patients (recurrent flash pulmonary edema, refractory HTN, progressive renal failure)
pearls: Monitor BP and kidney function regularly
Medication adherence (ACEi/ARB, statin, antiplatelet)
Nephrology/vascular follow-up

diagnoses.name: Restrictive Cardiomyopathy (RCM)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the heart muscle becomes rigid and less elastic, impairing diastolic filling.
workup: Echo (normal LV size, biatrial enlargement, impaired diastolic filling, normal/small LV cavity)
Cardiac MRI (fibrosis, infiltrative disease)
ECG (low voltage, arrhythmias)
BNP, iron studies, SPEP/UPEP (amyloidosis), genetic testing if indicated
Endomyocardial biopsy in select cases
management: Treat underlying cause (amyloidosis, hemochromatosis, sarcoidosis)
Diuretics for volume management (cautious)
Rate/rhythm control for AF, anticoagulation
Advanced therapies (transplant) if refractory
pearls: Monitor volume status, renal function
Serial imaging for progression
Adherence to therapy, report edema/ascites
Genetic counseling for inherited forms
Cardiology follow-up; specialty clinics if infiltrative disease

diagnoses.name: Restrictive Cardiomyopathy (RCM)
diagnoses.description: Cardiac muscle disease characterized by impaired ventricular filling with preserved systolic function, resulting in elevated filling pressures.
features: May have systemic symptoms if infiltrative disease
workup: Echocardiogram: Key diagnostic test [WHY: Shows normal LV size, biatrial enlargement, impaired diastolic filling, preserved EF]
Findings: restrictive filling pattern, elevated E/e' ratio, enlarged atria
Cardiac MRI: Superior tissue characterization [WHY: Identifies infiltrative diseases, fibrosis patterns, guides biopsy]
Late gadolinium enhancement patterns help differentiate causes
ECG: Often abnormal [WHY: Low voltage suggests infiltrative disease, conduction abnormalities common]
Findings: low voltage, arrhythmias, conduction blocks
Right heart catheterization: Confirms diagnosis [WHY: Shows equalization of diastolic pressures, square root sign]
Laboratory studies: Screen for systemic diseases [WHY: Identifies treatable causes]
BNP elevated, SPEP/UPEP (amyloidosis), iron studies (hemochromatosis)
Endomyocardial biopsy: Often necessary [WHY: Provides tissue diagnosis for infiltrative diseases]
Genetic testing: If familial disease suspected [WHY: Identifies inherited forms]
management: Treat underlying cause when possible [WHY: May halt or reverse disease progression]
Amyloidosis: tafamidis (TTR), chemotherapy (AL), supportive care
Hemochromatosis: phlebotomy or chelation therapy
Sarcoidosis: corticosteroids and immunosuppression
Diuretics: Cautious use for volume management [WHY: Improves symptoms but patients preload-dependent]
Rate and rhythm control: For atrial fibrillation [WHY: Maintain atrial contribution to filling]
Anticoagulation: For atrial fibrillation or high risk [WHY: High thromboembolic risk due to enlarged atria]
Heart transplantation: Advanced cases with poor prognosis [WHY: Definitive therapy for end-stage disease]
Avoid aggressive diuresis: Patients are preload-sensitive
Palliative care: For systemic diseases with poor prognosis
pearls: Least common form of cardiomyopathy but highest mortality
Must differentiate from constrictive pericarditis (surgical vs medical treatment)
Cardiac amyloidosis: Look for carpal tunnel, macroglossia, periorbital purpura
TTR amyloidosis: Often affects elderly males, may be misdiagnosed as HFpEF
Hemochromatosis: Bronze diabetes, arthropathy, hepatomegaly
Sarcoidosis: Pulmonary involvement, lymphadenopathy, skin lesions
Endomyocardial fibrosis: Rare, associated with eosinophilia
Prognosis depends on underlying etiology and response to treatment
Genetic counseling indicated for familial forms

diagnoses.name: Shock - Comprehensive Guide
diagnoses.description: Inadequate tissue perfusion and oxygen delivery resulting in cellular dysfunction. Four main types: hypovolemic, obstructive, distributive, and cardiogenic.
features: General features: ↓BP → ↓MAP → organ malperfusion → organ failure
Shock Index (SI) = HR/SBP: Normal <1.0, SI >1.0 suggests shock
Reflex tachycardia (except AV blocks, β-blocker overdose, neurogenic shock)
Organ-specific complications: Encephalopathy, NSTEMI, AKI, bowel ischemia, ischemic hepatitis
workup: Shock Index calculation: HR/SBP [WHY: Simple bedside tool to identify shock - >1.0 suggests shock, can detect shock before BP drops below 90 mmHg]
Lactate level: MOST IMPORTANT single test [WHY: Best marker of tissue hypoperfusion and cellular oxygen debt - >2 mmol/L significant, >4 mmol/L severe]
Lactate trends guide resuscitation effectiveness - elevated lactate = anaerobic metabolism from poor perfusion
Complete Blood Count (CBC) [WHY: Identifies shock type and complications]
Hemoglobin: Assess for blood loss (hypovolemic shock)
WBC with differential: Infection (sepsis/distributive shock)
Platelets: Bleeding risk assessment, DIC screening
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP) [WHY: Assesses organ function and metabolic consequences]
Creatinine: Kidney function (prerenal AKI common in shock)
Anion gap >12: Suggests metabolic acidosis
Electrolytes: K+ abnormalities affect cardiac function
Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) [WHY: Quantifies acid-base status and oxygenation]
pH <7.35 with base excess <-5 = metabolic acidosis
Confirms tissue hypoperfusion, guides ventilator management
Troponin: Rule out cardiac causes [WHY: MI can cause cardiogenic shock OR be complication of shock - demand ischemia from hypotension common]
Liver Function Tests (LFTs) [WHY: Detects 'shock liver' from prolonged hypoperfusion - AST/ALT >1000 suggests ischemic hepatitis]
Swan-Ganz catheter: For undifferentiated shock [WHY: Differentiates shock types when etiology unclear - guides targeted therapy]
Hemodynamic differentiation by Swan-Ganz values:
Hypovolemic: ↓CVP, ↓PCWP, ↓CI, ↑SVR, ↓SvO2
Cardiogenic: ↑CVP, ↑PCWP, ↓CI, ↑SVR, ↓SvO2
Distributive: ↓CVP, ↓PCWP, ↑CI, ↓↓SVR, ↑SvO2
Obstructive: ↑CVP, variable PCWP, ↓CI, ↑SVR, ↓SvO2
management: Hypovolemic: IV fluids (crystalloids) for plasma loss, blood products for blood loss
Obstructive: Treat cause - pericardiocentesis (tamponade), chest tube (tension PTX), tPA (PE)
Distributive: Treat cause + vasopressors if MAP <65 mmHg
Cardiogenic: Inotropes (dobutamine, milrinone) + mechanical support (IABP, ECMO)
General supportive care: Maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg, address metabolic complications
Serial lactate monitoring q2-4h during resuscitation
Organ support: CRRT for AKI, ventilatory support, stress ulcer prophylaxis
pearls: Distributive shock is the ONLY type with ↓↓SVR (others have compensatory ↑SVR)
Neurogenic and cardiogenic shock are ONLY types with hypotension + bradycardia
Swan-Ganz findings: Hypovolemic (↓CVP,↓PCWP,↓CI,↑SVR), Obstructive (↑CVP,↓PCWP,↓CI,↑SVR)
Swan-Ganz findings: Cardiogenic (↑CVP,↑PCWP,↓CI,↑SVR), Distributive (↓CVP,↓PCWP,↑CI,↓SVR)
Avoid IV fluids in cardiogenic shock (↑pulmonary edema)
Early recognition key: Shock index and lactate before obvious hypotension
Documentation: Include shock index, specific hemodynamic parameters, response to interventions
